{{islam by country}} The history of '''Islam in [[Japan]]''' is relatively brief in relation to the [[religion]]'s longstanding presence in other nearby countries. Islam is one of the smallest minority faiths in Japan, having more adherents in the country than the [[Bahá'í Faith in Japan|Bahá'í faith]], but fewer than [[Christianity in Japan|Christianity]]. There were isolated occasions of Muslims in Japan before the 19th century. Today, Muslims are made up of largely immigrant communities, as well as smaller ethnic Japanese community.<ref name="KY"/>
In 2016, Japan accepted 0.3% of [[refugee]] applicants, many of whom are Muslim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2017/06/lives-limbo-japan-accepts-refugees-170608122312650.html|title=Lives in limbo: Why Japan accepts so few refugees|first=Annette|last=Ekin|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]}}</ref>
==Early history== There are isolated records of contact between Islam and Japan before the opening of the country in 1853, possibly as early as the 1700s; some Muslims did arrive in earlier centuries, although these were isolated incidents.
===Medieval records=== [[File:Kashgari map.jpg|thumb|Kashgari's map features an island on the top, corresponding to the east from China.]] The earliest Muslim records of Japan can be found in the works of the Muslim cartographer [[Ibn Khordadbeh]], who has been understood by [[Michael Jan de Goeje]] to mention Japan as the "lands of [[Wāḳwāḳ|Waqwaq]]" twice: ''East of China are the lands of Waqwaq, which are so rich in gold that the inhabitants make the chains for their dogs and the collars for their monkeys of this metal. They manufacture tunics woven with gold. Excellent ebony wood is found there.” And: “Gold and ebony are exported from Waqwaq.''<ref>[http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/200504/the.seas.of.sindbad.htm Saudi Aramco World: The Seas of Sindbad], [[Paul Lunde]]</ref> [[Mahmud al-Kashgari|Mahmud Kashgari]]'s 11th century atlas indicates the land routes of the [[Silk Road]] and [[Japan]] in the map's easternmost extent.
===Yuan Dynasty's conflict with Japan=== {{main|Mongol invasions of Japan}} [[File:Mōko Shūrai Ekotoba 2.jpg|thumb|right|The samurai Suenaga facing Mongol arrows and bombs. ''[[Mōko Shūrai Ekotoba]]'' (蒙古襲来絵詞), circa 1293]] Within Kublai's court, his most trusted governors and advisers appointed by meritocracy with the essence of multiculturalism were: [[Semu]], [[Hui people|Hui]], [[Koreans]] and [[Chinese people|Chinese]].<ref>[http://www.muslimheritage.com/uploads/1001_Years_of_Missing_Martial_Arts%20.pdf 1001 Years of Missing Martial Arts]</ref><ref name="元史">[[History of Yuan]] 『元史』 卷十二 本紀第十二 世祖九 至元十九年七月壬戌（August 9, 1282）「高麗国王請、自造船百五十艘、助征日本。」</ref> Because the [[Wokou]] extended support to the crumbling [[Song dynasty]], [[Kublai Khan]] initiated the [[Mongol invasions of Japan]].
The court of the [[Goryeo]] supplied [[Koreans|Korean]] troops and an ocean-going naval force for the Mongol campaigns. Despite the opposition of some of his Confucian-trained advisers, Kublai decided to invade [[Japan]], [[Burma]], [[Vietnam]], and [[Mongol invasion of Java|Java]], following the suggestions of some of his Mongol officials. He also attempted to subjugate peripheral lands such as [[Sakhalin]], where its indigenous people eventually submitted to the Mongols by 1308, after Kublai's death. <gallery> File:MokoShuraiE-Kotoba I.jpg|Mongol soldiers, second version File:MokoShuraiE-Kotoba III.jpg|Mongol ships, second version File:YuanJunk(14thcentury).jpg|Painting of a 14th-century prized Yuan dynasty [[Junk (ship)|junk]] </gallery>
===Ming dynasty records=== [[File:Ryukyuan mission in Edo.jpg|thumb|A Ryukyuan [[Ryukyuan missions to Edo|embassy]] (favorable to [[Ming dynasty]], [[China]]) arrive in [[Edo]].]] During the 14th century, [[Hongwu Emperor]] of the [[Ming dynasty]] made [[Ryukyu Kingdom]] a tributary vassal, and ethnic Chinese settlers consolidated the islands for their ruler in [[Nanjing]].
During that period there was contact between the [[Hui people|Hui]], general [[Lan Yu (general)|Lan Yu]] of the [[Ming dynasty]] and the [[Japanese swordsmithing|swordsmiths of Japan]]. According to Chinese sources, Lan Yu owned 10,000 [[Katana]], Hongwu Emperor was displeased with the general's links with [[Kyoto]] and more than 15,000 people were implicated for alleged treason and executed.<ref>(二十六年二月，錦衣衛指揮蔣瓛告玉謀反，下吏鞫訊。獄辭雲：「玉同景川侯曹震、鶴慶侯張翼、舳艫侯硃壽、東莞伯何榮及吏部尚書詹徽、戶部侍郎傅友文等謀為變，將伺帝出耤田舉事。」獄具，族誅之。列侯以下坐黨夷滅者不可勝數。手詔佈告天下，條列爰書為《逆臣錄》。至九月，乃下詔曰：「藍賊為亂，謀泄，族誅者萬五千人。自今胡黨、藍黨概赦不問。」胡謂丞相惟庸也。於是元功宿將相繼盡矣。凡列名《逆臣錄》者，一公、十三侯、二伯。葉升前坐事誅，胡玉等諸小侯皆別見。其曹震、張翼、張溫、陳桓、硃壽、曹興六侯，附著左方。)</ref><ref>Others implicated in the Lan Yu Case include: Han Xun (韓勛), Marquis of Dongping (東平侯); Cao Tai (曹泰), Marquis of Xuanning (宣寧侯); Cao Xing (曹興), Marquis of Huaiyuan (懷遠侯); Ye Sheng (葉升), Marquis of Jingning (靖寧侯); Cao Zhen (曹震), Marquis of Jingchuan (景川侯); Zhang Wen (張溫), Marquis of Huining (會寧侯); Chen Huan (陳桓), Marquis of Puding (普定侯); Zhang Yi (張翼), Marquis of Heqing (鶴慶侯); Zhu Shou (朱壽), Marquis of Zhulu (舳艫侯); Chahan (察罕), Marquis of Haixi (海西侯); Sun Ke (孫恪), Marquis of Quanning (全寧侯); He Rong (何榮), Count of Dongguan (東莞伯); Sang Jing (桑敬), Count of Huixian (徽先伯)</ref>
===Portuguese records=== Early European accounts of Muslims and their contacts with Japan were maintained by [[Portugal|Portuguese]] sailors who mention a passenger aboard their ship, an [[Arab]] who had preached [[Islam]] to the people of Japan. He had sailed to the islands in [[Malacca]] in 1555.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.IslamicJapanese.in|title=Islam In Japan|publisher=Islamic Japanese|accessdate=2013}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0x1Io6VOuAIC&pg=PA518&dq=Portuguese+ship+Malacca+in+1555+Arab+Japanese.&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IB1-UuDWEOH17AbOr4C4DQ&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Portuguese%20ship%20Malacca%20in%201555%20Arab%20Japanese.&f=false Asia in the Making of Europe, Volume I: The Century of Discovery.] - [[Donald F. Lach]] - Google Books</ref>
===Modern records=== The first modern{{clarify|date=August 2015|reason= "modern" is after when?}} Muslim contacts{{clarify|date=August 2015|reason="contacts" is between who and Muslims?}} were with Indonesians who served aboard British and Dutch ships in the late 19th century.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
In the late 1870s, the [[Sirah Rasul Allah|biography of Muhammad]] was translated into Japanese. This helped Islam spread and reach the Japanese people, but only as a part of the history of cultures.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
Another important contact was made in 1890 when the [[Ottoman Empire]] dispatched a naval vessel to Japan for the purpose of saluting the visit of Japanese [[Prince Komatsu Akihito]] to Constantinople several years earlier. This frigate was called the ''[[Ertuğrul (Ottoman frigate)|Ertugrul]]'', and was destroyed in a storm along the coast of Wakayama Prefecture on September 16, 1890.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
==Early 20th century== [[File:Abdürreşit-İbrahim-Efendi-1857-1944-ve-Çocukları.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Abdurreshid Ibrahim]] (center), Russian ([[Tatar]]) migrant to [[Meiji period|Meiji]] Japan, who became the first imam of [[Tokyo Camii]].]] In the wake of the [[October Revolution]], several hundred Turko-[[Tatar]] Muslim refugees from [[Turkestan ASSR|Central Asia]] and [[RSFSR|Russia]] were given asylum in Japan, settling in several main cities and formed small communities. Some Japanese converted to Islam through contact with these Muslims. Historian Caeser E. Farah documented that in 1909 the Russian-born writer [[Abdurreshid Ibrahim]] (1857–1944), was the first Muslim who successfully converted the first ethnic Japanese, when Kotaro Yamaoka converted in 1909 in Bombay after contacting Ibrahim and took the name Omar Yamaoka.<ref name="CEFBook">{{cite book|last=E. Farah|first=Caesar|title=Islam: Beliefs and Observations|publisher=Barron's Educational Series; 7th Revised edition|date=25 April approximately 600, 2003|isbn=978-0-7641-2226-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sAlDjVO7SowC&pg=PA291&dq=islam+in+japan&lr=&as_brr=3#PPA291,M1}}</ref> Yamaoka became the first Japanese to go on the [[Hajj]]. Yamaoka and Ibrahim were traveling with the support of nationalistic Japanese groups like [[Black Dragon Society]] (Kokuryūkai). Yamaoka in fact had been with the [[Japanese Secret Intelligence Services|intelligence service]] in [[Manchuria]] since the [[Russo-Japanese war]]. His official reason for traveling was to seek the Sultan's approval for building a mosque in Tokyo. This approval was granted in 1910, and on 12 May 1938, the [[Tokyo Mosque]], was finally completed, with generous financial support from the [[zaibatsu]]. Its first imams were Abdul-Rashid Ibrahim and Abdülhay Kurban Ali (Muhammed-Gabdulkhay Kurbangaliev) (1889–1972). However, Japan’s first mosque, the Kobe Mosque was built in 1935, with the support of the Turko-Tatar community of traders there.<ref name="MPIslam"/> On 12 May 1938, a Mosque was dedicated in Tokyo.<ref name=R&A890p1>{{Harvnb|R&A No. 890|1943|p=1}}</ref> Another early Japanese convert was Bunpachiro Ariga, who about the same time as Yamaoka went to India for trading purposes and converted to Islam under the influence of local Muslims there, and subsequently took the name Ahmed Ariga. Yamada Toajiro was for almost 20 years from 1892 the only resident Japanese trader in Constantinople.<ref>His memoirs: Toruko Gakan, Tokyo 1911</ref> During this time he served unofficially as [[consul (representative)|consul]]. He converted to Islam, and took the name Abdul Khalil, and made a pilgrimage to Mecca on his way home.
The [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]] was established in 1935 in Japan.<ref name="around_the_world_137">''Ahmadiyya Muslim Mosques Around the World'', p. 137</ref>
===Japanese nationalists and Islam=== [[File:Okawa_Shumei_c.jpg|thumb|left|[[Shūmei Ōkawa]], a [[Japanese nationalism|nationalistic]] [[Pan-Asianism|Pan-Asian]] writer described as the "Japanese Goebbels", completed the first Japanese translation of the Quran.]] In the late [[Meiji period]], close relations were forged between Japanese military elites with an [[Pan-Asianism|Asianist]] agenda and Muslims to find a common cause with those suffering under the yoke of Western hegemony.<ref>Japan's Global Claim to Asia and the World of Islam: Transnational Nationalism and World Power, 1900-1945. S Esenbel. The American Historical Review 109 (4), 1140-1170</ref> In 1906, widespread campaigns were aimed at Muslim nations with journals reporting that a Congress of religions was to be held in Japan where the Japanese would seriously consider adopting Islam as the national religion and that the Emperor was at the point of becoming a Muslim.<ref>Bodde, Derk. “Japan and the Muslims of China.” Far Eastern Survey, vol. 15, no. 20, 1946, pp. 311–313., www.jstor.org/stable/3021860.</ref>
Nationalistic organizations like the Ajia Gikai were instrumental in petitioning the Japanese government on matters such as officially recognizing Islam, along with [[Shinto]]ism, [[Christianity]] and [[Buddhism]] as a religion in Japan, and in providing funding and training to Muslim resistance movements in Southeast Asia, such as the Hizbullah, a resistance group funded by Japan in the Dutch Indies. The {{nihongo|Greater Japan Muslim League|大日本回教協会|Dai Nihon Kaikyō Kyōkai}} founded in 1930, was the first official Islamic organisation in Japan. It had the support of imperialistic circles during [[World War II]], and caused an "Islamic Studies Boom".<ref>Most of its produced literature is preserved in the [[Waseda University Library]]({{cite web |url=http://dspace.wul.waseda.ac.jp/dspace/bitstream/2065/3973/1/100189_15.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306124103/http://dspace.wul.waseda.ac.jp/dspace/bitstream/2065/3973/1/100189_15.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-06 |df= }} Catalogue)</ref> During this period, over 100 books and journals on Islam were published in Japan. While these organizations had their primary aim in intellectually equipping Japan's forces and intellectuals with better knowledge and understanding of the Islamic world, dismissing them as mere attempts to further Japan's aims for a "[[Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere|Greater Asia]]" does not reflect the nature of depth of these studies. Japanese and Muslim academia in their common aims of defeating [[Western imperialism|Western colonialism]] had been forging ties since the early twentieth century, and with the destruction of the last remaining Muslim power, the Ottoman Empire, the advent of hostilities in [[World War II]] and the possibility of the same fate awaiting Japan, these academic and political exchanges and the alliances created reached a head. Therefore, they were extremely active in forging links with academia and Muslim leaders and revolutionaries, many of whom were invited to Japan.
[[Shūmei Ōkawa]], by far the highest-placed and most prominent figure in both Japanese government and academia in the matter of Japanese-Islamic exchange and studies, managed to complete his translation of the ''[[Qur'an]]'' in prison, while being prosecuted as an alleged [[class-A war criminal]] by the victorious Allied forces for being an 'organ of propaganda'.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Okawa-Shumei|title=Okawa Shumei|publisher=Britannica|accessdate=6 March 2017|date=20 July 1998}}</ref> Charges were dropped for his erratic behaviour officially; however historians have speculated that the weakness of the charges against him was more likely the true reason. While Okawa did display unusual behaviour during the trial such as rapping on the head of [[Hideki Tōjō]], he also stated that the trial was a farce and unworthy of being called one.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} He was transferred to a hospital on official claims of mental instability and then prison, and freed not long thereafter, dying as Muslim in 1957 after a quiet life where he continued lecturing, on his return to his home village and his wife, who survived him. He claimed to have seen visions of [[Muhammad]] in his sleep.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
==Post–World War II== The Turks have been the biggest Muslim community in Japan until recently.<ref name="MIJ">{{cite news|url=http://www.missionislam.com/knowledge/japan.htm|title=Islam in Japan|publisher=Mission Islam.com|accessdate=27 December 2008}}</ref> The Japanese invasion of China and South East Asian regions during the Second World War brought the Japanese in contact with Muslims. Those who converted to Islam through them returned to Japan and established in 1953 the first Japanese Muslim organisation, the "Japan Muslim Association", which was officially granted recognition as a religious organization by the Japanese government in June 1968.<ref name="MPIslam"/> The second president of the association was the [[Umar Mita]], who was typical of the old generation, learning Islam in the territories occupied by the [[Japanese Empire]]. He was working for the [[Manshu Railway Company]], which virtually controlled the Japanese territory in the northeastern province of China at that time. Through his contacts with Chinese Muslims, he became a Muslim in Peking. When he returned to Japan after the war, he made the Hajj, the first Japanese in the post-war period to do so. He also made a Japanese translation of the Qur'an from a Muslim perspective for the first time. [[Aljazeera]] also made a documentary regarding Islam and Japan called "Road to Hajj – Japan".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BPa4OPuYQs0|title=Road to Hajj — Japan - 26 Nov 09 - Pt 1|publisher=YouTube|date=26 November 2009|accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref>
The economic boom in the country in the 1980s saw an influx of immigrants to Japan, including from majority Muslim nations. These immigrants and their descendants form the majority of Muslims in the country. Today, there are Muslim student associations at some Japanese universities.<ref name="MPIslam"/>
==Muslim demographics== In 1941, one of the chief sponsors of the Tokyo Mosque asserted that the number of Muslims in Japan numbered 600, with just three or four being native Japanese.<ref name=R&A890p1 /> Some sources state that in 1982 the Muslims numbered 30,000 (half were natives).<ref name="CEFBook"/> Of the ethnically Japanese Muslims, the majority are thought to be ethnic Japanese women who married immigrant Muslims who arrived during the economic boom of the 1980s, but there are also a small number of intellectuals, including university professors, who have converted.<ref name="JapanWomenIslam"/><ref name="MPIslam"/> Most estimates of the Muslim population give a range around 100,000 total.<ref name="CEFBook"/><ref name="MPIslam">{{cite web|url=http://www.asiaquarterly.com/content/view/168/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202212653/http://www.asiaquarterly.com/content/view/168/|archivedate=2 February 2007|title=Islami in Japan|last=Penn|first=Michael|work=Harvard Asia Quarterly|accessdate=28 December 2008}}</ref><ref>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2008/108408.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2008 - Japan]</ref> Islam remains a minority religion in Japan, and there is no evidence as to whether its numbers are increasing. Conversion is more prominent among young ethnic Japanese married women, as claimed by ''The Modern Religion'' as early as the 1990s.<ref name="JapanWomenIslam">{{cite news|url=http://www.themodernreligion.com/women/women_japan.htm|title=Marriages lead women into Islam in Japan|last=Y. Nakano|first=Lynne|author2=Japan Times Newspaper|date=November 19, 1992|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=27 December 2008}}</ref> The true size of the current Muslim population in Japan remains a matter of speculation. Japanese scholars such as Hiroshi Kojima of the National Institute of Population and Social Security Research and Keiko Sakurai of Waseda University suggest a Muslim population of around 70,000, of which perhaps 90% are resident foreigners and about 10% native Japanese.<ref name="KY">{{cite news|url=http://japanfocus.org/-Kawakami-Yasunori/2436/article.html|title=Local Mosques and the Lives of Muslims in Japan|last=Yasunori|first=Kawakami|author2=JapanFocus.org |date=May 30, 2007|publisher=JapanFocus.org |accessdate=27 December 2008}}</ref><ref name="MPIslam"/> Of the immigrant communities, in order of population size, are Indonesians, Indians, Pakistanis, Bangladeshis, and Iranians.<ref name="MPIslam"/> The Pew Research Center estimated that there were 185,000 Muslims in Japan in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2011/01/27/table-muslim-population-by-country/|title=Table: Muslim Population by Country|publisher=Pew Research Center|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=19 March 2017}}</ref>
==Mosques== <gallery> File:Kobe-mosque3.jpg|[[Kobe Mosque]], Japan's first mosque, built in Indian style in 1935 by [[Jan Josef Švagr]] File:Tokyo Camii 2009.jpg|[[Tokyo Camii]] Mosque with adjoining Turkish culture center File:Bait-ul-Ahad The Japan Mosque.JPG|[[The Japan Mosque]], the largest in the country, is the only [[Ahmadiyya]] mosque in Japan </gallery>
According to japanfocus.org, {{as of|2009|lc=on}} there were 30 to 40 single-story mosques in Japan plus another 100 or more apartment rooms set aside for prayers in the absence of more suitable facilities. 90% of these mosques use the 2nd floor for religious activities and the first floor as a halal shop (Imported food; mainly from Indonesia and Malaysia), due to financial problems, as membership is too low to cover the expenses. Most of these Mosques have only a capacity of 30 to 50 people. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japanfocus.org/products/details/2436 |title=JapanFocus |publisher=JapanFocus |accessdate=2 May 2010 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219234947/http://japanfocus.org/products/details/2436 |archivedate=February 19, 2009 }}</ref>
==Notable Muslims== * [[Ryoichi Mita]] * [[Antonio Inoki]] * [[Dewi Sukarno]] * [[Abdul Hakim Sani Brown]]
==See also== {{portal|Islam|Japan}} * [[Ahmadiyya in Japan]] * [[Religion in Japan]] * [[Shingetsu Institute]], which tracks Japanese–Islamic relations from an academic perspective.
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}

February 1986/Jamad al-Awal 1406 * Hiroshi Kojima, "Demographic Analysis of Muslims in Japan," The 13th KAMES and 5th AFMA International Symposium, Pusan, 2004 * Michael Penn, "Islam in Japan: Adversity and Diversity," ''Harvard Asia Quarterly'', Vol. 10, No. 1, Winter 2006 * Keiko Sakurai, ''Nihon no Musurimu Shakai'' (Japan's Muslim Society), Chikuma Shobo, 2003 * Esenbel, Selcuk; ''Japanese Interest in the Ottoman Empire;'' in: Edstrom, Bert; The Japanese and Europe: Images and Perceptions; Surrey 2000 * Esenbel, Selcuk; Inaba Chiharū; ''The Rising Sun and the Turkish Crescent;'' İstanbul 2003, {{ISBN|975-518-196-2}} * ''A fin-de-siecle Japanese Romantic in Istanbul: The life of Yamada Torajirō and his Turoko gakan;'' Bull [[SOAS]], Vol. LIX-2 (1996), S 237-52 ... * {{cite journal|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/docs/DOC_0000599220.pdf|title=Japanese Infiltration Among the Muslims Throughout the World (R&A No. 890)|date=15 May 1943|author=Research and Analysis Branch|work=Office of Strategic Services|publisher=U.S. Central Intelligence Agency Library|ref={{Harvid|R&A No. 890|1943}}}}
==External links== *[http://materiaislamica.com/index.php/History_of_the_Muslim_Peoples_%26_Islamic_Culture_in_Japan_(1700%E2%80%94Present) History of the Muslim Peoples & Islamic Culture in Japan (1700—Present)] at ''Materia Islamica''. * [http://www.islamicjapanese.blogspot.com/ Islamic Website Japan] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cWbXYdGHqdI/ Video Of Islam in Japan] * [http://www.dokidoki.ne.jp/home2/islam/ Islamic Website Japan] * [http://www2.dokidoki.ne.jp/islam/benri/benriindex.htm Mosques in Japan] * [http://islamqa.com/special/index.php?subsite=153&ln=jpn Islam-QA Japanese Islamic website offering a comprehensive library of Islamic references and resources in the Japanese language] * [http://www.icoj.org/ Islamic Circle of Japan] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YGJjxVWkLpc Videoclip of the Tokyo Mosque] * [http://www.islamcenter.or.jp/ Islamic Center Japan] * [http://english.aljazeera.net/focus/hajj/2009/11/2009111011825150196.html Aljazeera English video – Japanese Muslims preparing for Hajj] * [http://www.iqra.jp/ TOKYO IQRA INTERNATIONAL SCHOOL]

{{unreferenced|date=November 2016}} '''Jiang Ziwen''' ({{zh|first=t|t={{linktext|蔣|子|文}}|s=蒋子文|p=Jiǎng Zǐwén}}) was a ''[[wei (rank)|wei]]'' of [[Moling (China)|Moling]] (modern [[Nanjing]]) [[county (China)|county]] in China during the [[Eastern Han Dynasty]].
Originally from [[Guangling District|Guangling]], now a district of [[Yangzhou]] in [[Jiangsu Province]], he became addicted to wine and women, but was nonetheless recognized for his unusual [[phrenology]]. In the course of putting down an insurrection, he was killed by a blow to the forehead.
During the [[Three Kingdoms]] era, people repeatedly reported encountering his spirit, so that [[Sun Quan]] called him the [[shanshen|God]] of [[Purple Mountain (Nanjing)|Bell Mountain]] ({{zh|labels=no|first=t|t={{linktext|鐘山|山神}} |s=钟山山神 |p=Zhōngshān Shānshén}}), a peak near Nanjing which was then also known as Jiangshan ({{lang|zh-hant|蔣山}}).
Following the introduction of [[Buddhism in China|Buddhism]] to China and the popularization of its [[god of the dead|king of the dead]] [[Yama (Buddhism)|Yama]], Jiang was placed in charge of the first of his [[Diyu|ten hells]] as the Qinguang King ({{zh|labels=no|first=t|t={{linktext|秦|廣|王|蔣}} |s=秦广王蒋 |p=Qínguǎng Wáng Jiǎng}}).

{{Infobox organization | name = LALMA | native_name = La Asociacion Latino Musulmana de America | native_name_lang = Spanish | logo = Logo_for_LALMA.png | abbreviation = | formation = September 1999 | founder = | founding_location = Los Angeles, California | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = Non-profit organization | purpose = Promoting understanding of Islam among Latino Muslims | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = | services = | membership = | membership_year = | language = Spanish | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[Marta Felicitas Galedary]] | key_people = | affiliations = | website = [http://www.lalma.net/ lalma.net] | formerly = Los Angeles Latino Muslims Association }}
'''LALMA''' is a not-for-profit organization that was established in 1999 in response to the need for Spanish-language resources on [[Islam]]. LALMA began with a group of five [[Hispanic and Latino American Muslims|Latino Muslims]] from [[Los Angeles]] led by [[Marta Felicitas Galedary]] began having regular meetings to learn about Islam in the Spanish language. According to its mission statement, LALMA "promotes a better understanding of Islam to the Spanish speaking community and establishes a forum of spiritual nurturing and social support to Latino Muslims, building bridges among the monotheistic community and advocating for [[social justice]] in accordance with Islamic values."<ref>{{Cite web|title = Brief History of LALMA | url = http://www.lalma.net/quienes-somos/|website = lalma.net|access-date = 2017-01-07}}</ref> Initially LALMA stood for '''Los Angeles Latino Muslims Association''', but after a restructuring to accommodate its growth, LALMA was renamed to '''La Asociacion Latino Musulmana de America'''.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Latino_Muslim_by_Design.html?id=vRcRngEACAAJ |author=Morales, Harold Daniel |title=Latino Muslim by Design|publisher=University of California, Riverside|isbn=9781267729910|year=2012|accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref><ref name=misreading>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8SxpAgAAQBAJ |author=Wimbush, Vincent L. |title=MisReading America: Scriptures and Difference.|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199975426|year=2013|accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Szm2BQAAQBAJ |author=Laderman, Gary |title=Religion and American Cultures: Tradition, Diversity, and Popular Expression|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781322431697|year=2014|accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jS_e5M1jZ18C |author=Ahmed, Akbar |title=Journey into America: The Challenge of Islam|publisher=Brookings Institution Press|isbn=9780815703877|year=2010|accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ljgp7cNG_zw |title=Hispanics are Embracing Islam in America |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=2010-01-30 |accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref><ref name=amel>{{cite web|author=Amel S. Abdullah |url=http://hispanicmuslims.com/articles/islammosaic.html |title=Latino Reverts Add to Mosaic of Islam |publisher=Southern California InFocus |date=2006-02-01 |accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref><ref name=ma>{{cite web|author=Jason Ma |url=http://www.neontommy.com/2010/03/latino-muslim-community-contin |title=Latino Muslim Community On The Rise In U.S. |publisher=Annenberg Media Center |date=2010-03-04 |accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Anthony Chiorazzi |url=http://bustedhalo.com/features/from-cross-to-crescent |title=From Cross to Crescent |publisher=Busted Halo |date=2007-05-08 |accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref><ref name=reddy>{{cite web|author=Mrinalini Reddy |url=https://news21.com/story/2007/08/22/even_as_islam_booms_its |title=Even as Islam Booms, Its Many Faces Can Deter Converts|publisher=Medill Journalism |date=2007-08-23 |accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref>
Each Sunday morning, LALMA members gather to attend [[Arabic]] lessons, receive instruction on the [[Quran]] and the biography of [[Muhammad]] ([[Prophetic biography|sirah]]), and discuss issues of interest to Muslim converts.<ref name=misreading/><ref name=reddy/> They regularly have guest lectures on different aspects of Islam. They meet at various mosques in Southern California including Masjid Omar ibn Al-Khattab and the [[Islamic Center of Southern California]]. LALMA also provides [[cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] courses, first aid, and community safety courses as well as teen counseling and support to Latino [[dawah]] programs. They host and participate in interfaith events, such as with the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles]]. LALMA sponsors events such as conferences on the Islamic roots of Spain and yearly activities during [[Ramadan]].<ref name=misreading/><ref name=amel/><ref name=ma/>

'''Lakhanpal''' is one of the sub-caste among other sub-castes of Saraswat Brahmins. The gotra of Punjabi lakhanpal's is kaushal. It is a surname adopted mainly by [[Saraswat Brahmin]] in [[North India]] ([[Punjab (India)|Punjab]], [[Himachal Pradesh]], [[Kashmir]] states). There are two categories of Brahmins in India. One is saraswat Brahmins & second is gaur Brahmins. Saraswat Brahmins do not accept any kind of eatables or anything (MINSYA) which people give to them on various Hindu dates as per Hindu calendar as other Brahmins do.Saraswat Brahmins are the most respected people from the beginning in India. Jathere Lakhanpal are situated in Punjab at PHAGWARA , NAKODAR ROAD NEAR BY LAKHANPAL VILLAGE . The Jathere of Lakhanpal's are very much worshipped by their descendants. A newly married couple or if a child is born in the family the related go there for a wish of receiving blessings and for giving thanks. Normally one can go on any Day, but most worshipped day is a day before First Navratra in the Month of April. In the year 2016 the most worshipped day is mosyly worshiped in August and September . On this day, lots of people belonging to the kaushal clan come from many places, even from far away to worship Jathere. More than 200 families gather to worship Jathere.
There are no other Jathere of Lakhanpal caste and Kaushal Gotra other than situated in village LAKHANPAL .
==References== Lakhanpal jathere is celebrated on bhadon duasti

revision.text: '''Louise McWhirter''' was one of the pioneers in [[financial astrology]], which is the use of astrology to forecast the financial markets.{{Cite book|title=McWhirter Theory of Stock Market Forecasting|last=McWhirter|first=Louise|publisher=American Federation of Astrologers|year=2008|isbn=978-0866905855|editor-last=Riske|editor-first=Kris Brandt|location=|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=Gann for the Active Trader|last=Ferrera|first=Daniel T.|publisher=Sacred Science Institute|year=2015|isbn=9781942418047|location=|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=The Astrology Book: The Encyclopedia of Heavenly Influences|last=Lewis|first=James R|publisher=Visible Ink Press|year=2003|isbn=9781578592463|location=|pages=}} In 1937, she published her only book, ''Astrology and Stock Market Forecasting''.{{Cite book|title=Astrology and Stock Market Forecasting|last=McWhirter|first=Louise|publisher=A S I Publishers|year=1977|isbn=9780882310343|location=|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=Financial Astrology|last=Williams|first=David|publisher=American Federation of Astrology|year=1984|isbn=9780866900454|location=|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=The Beginners Guide to the Financial Universe: An Introduction to the Role of the Sun, Moon, and Planets in Financial Markets|last=Skinner|first=Christeen H.|publisher=Nicolas-Hays|year=2017|isbn=9780892546404|location=|pages=}} Some believe that “Louise McWhirter” was only an alias of famous market forecaster [[William Delbert Gann|W. D. Gann]].{{Cite book|title=Stock Market Forecasting: The McWhirter Method De-Mystified|last=Bucholtz|first=M.G.|publisher=Wood Dragon Books|year=2014|isbn=978-0968537091|location=|pages=}} == McWhirter’s theory == [[File:Lunar orbit.png|thumb|The geocentric view of the movement of the Nodes, which has a cycle of 18.6 years approximately.]] === The Nodal cycle === McWhirter’s main theory was that the major of primary trend of business volume and finance is clearly pointed out by the 18.6-year cycle of the [[Lunar node|North Node]] as it passes through the [[Astrological sign|twelve signs of the zodiac]].{{Cite book|title=Time and Money: The Economy and the Planets|last=Gover|first=Robert|publisher=Hopewell Publications|year=2005|isbn=9780972690683|location=|pages=}} During a long-term trend, the four crucial points of the stock market are reached when the Node enters the four [[fixed sign]]s respectively: *[[Aquarius (astrology)|'''Aquarius''']]: This is the extreme low of business activity, the bottom of the cycle. *[[Pisces (astrology)|Pisces]]: The business activity turns up from the bottom. *[[Aries (astrology)|Aries]]: The business continues to go higher towards the normal level. * [[Taurus (astrology)|'''Taurus''']]: The business activity reaches a normal level, and the trend is going up. *[[Gemini (astrology)|Gemini]]: The business activity starts to go above the normal level. *[[Cancer (astrology)|Cancer]]: The business activity goes even higher. *[[Leo (astrology)|'''Leo''']]: This is the extreme high of business activity, the top of the cycle. *[[Virgo (astrology)|Virgo]]: The business activity fades from the top. *[[Libra (astrology)|Libra]]: The business continues to fall lower towards the normal level. *[[Scorpio (astrology)|'''Scorpio''']]: The business activity reaches a normal level, but the trend is going down. *[[Sagittarius (astrology)|Sagittarius]]: The business activity starts to fall below the normal level. *[[Capricorn (astrology)|Capricorn]]: The business activity approaches the bottom of the cycle. It has been noted that the four crucial signs (the top, bottom and two break-even points) correspond to the four heads of the [[cherub]]im in the [[Book of Ezekiel]].{{Cite book|title=Star Myths of the World|last=Mathisen|first=David Warner|publisher=Beowulf Books|year=2015|isbn=978-0996059022|location=|pages=}} Below is a table of [[List of stock market crashes and bear markets|stock market crashes]][http://blogs.smithsonianmag.com/history/2012/03/%E2%80%9Ckipper-und-wipper%E2%80%9D-rogue-traders-rogue-princes-rogue-bishops-and-the-german-financial-meltdown-of-1621-23/ "“Kipper und Wipper”: Rogue Traders, Rogue Princes, Rogue Bishops and the German Financial Meltdown of 1621-23"] by Mike Dash, ''Smithsonian'', March 29, 2012Dash, Mike "Tulipomania: The Story of the World's Most Coveted Flower & the Extraordinary Passions It Aroused" 2001James D. Henderson, Helen Delpar & Maurice P. Brungardt "A Reference Guide to Latin American History" Richard Weldon Editor – M.E.Sharpe Inc. 2000, ISBN I563247445 page 172, 2nd column, "1890" (2nd paragraph)[https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052748703957604575272791511469272 "Back to the Future: Lessons From the Forgotten 'Flash Crash' of 1962"][[Gary Previts]], Peter Walton & Peter Wolnizer "A Global History of Accounting, Financial Reporting And Public Policy; Americas – Volume 14B" [[University of Sydney|The University of Sydney]]/The Accounting Foundation, Emerald Group Publishing Limited 2011 {{ISBN|978-0-85724-811-4}} Page 41, from the last paragraph{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/02/27/china-shanghai-update-markets-emerge-cx_jc_vk_0227markets15.html|title=Black Tuesday In China|last=Chen|first=Shu-Ching Jean|date=27 February 2007|newspaper=Forbes|accessdate=25 September 2011|author2=Kwok, Vivian Wai-yin}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/7738874.stm|title=IMF approves $2.1bn Iceland loan|date=20 November 2008|accessdate=25 September 2011|publisher=BBC News}}{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-0822-financial-markets-20150821-story.html|title=Stock market suffers worst one-day drop since 2008|author1=Shan Li|date=August 21, 2015|accessdate=August 24, 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Times|author2=Andrea Chang|author3=Paresh Dave}} and the respective North Node locations. Please note that the motion of the North is retrograde by default, so that it always travels from West to East, in the opposite way of other planets. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" ! style="width: 100" |Name ! style="width: 30" |Date !Country ! class="unsortable" href="Lunar node" |North Node Location |- href="fixed sign" |[[Kipper und Wipper]] | href="Aquarius_(astrology)" |{{dts|1623|||format=dmy}}{{flagicon|Holy Roman Empire}} | href="Pisces (astrology)" |Left '''Scorpius''' into Libra in May 1623. |- | href="Taurus_(astrology)" |[[Tulip mania|Tulip mania Bubble]]{{dts|1637|||format=dmy}} | href="Gemini (astrology)" |{{flagicon|Netherlands}} | href="Cancer (astrology)" |Left '''Aquarius''' into Capricorn in April 1637. |- href="Virgo_(astrology)" |[[Mississippi Company|The Mississippi Bubble]] |{{dts|1720|||format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|Kingdom of France}} |Stayed in '''Leo''' for the whole year. |- href="Book of Ezekiel" |[[South Sea Company|South Sea Bubble of 1720]] | href="File:Keplers trigon.jpg" |{{dts|1720|||format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|UK}} | href="Jupiter" |Stayed in '''Leo''' for the whole year. |-Left '''Scorpius''' into Libra in April 1772. |- |[[Panic of 1792|Financial Crisis of 1791–92]] |{{dts|1791|||format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Left '''Scorpius''' in November 1790 and stayed in Libra for most of 1791-1792. |- href="Midheaven" | href="New York Stock Exchange" |[[Panic of 1819]] | href="Pisces_(astrology)" |{{dts|1819|||format=dmy}} | href="Neptune" |{{flagicon|USA}} |Left '''Taurus''' in October 1818 and stayed in Aries in 1819. |- | - |[[Panic of 1837]] |{{dts|1837|May|10|format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Left '''Taurus''' into Aries in May 1937. |- |[[Panic of 1847]] |{{dts|1847|||format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|UK}} |Left '''Scorpius''' in September 1846 and stayed in Libra in 1847. |- |- |[[Black Friday (1869)|Black Friday]] |{{dts|1869|Sep|24|format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Stayed in '''Leo''' for the whole year. |- |[[Panic of 1873]] |{{dts|1873|May|9|format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Stayed in '''Taurus''' for the whole year. |- |[[Paris Bourse crash of 1882]] |19 Jan 1882 |{{flagicon|France}} |Left Sagittarius into '''Scorpius''' in May 1882. |- |[[Panic of 1884]] |{{dts|1884|||format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Left '''Scorpius''' in December 1883 and stayed in Libra in 1884. |- |- |- |[[Panic of 1901]] |{{dts|1901|May|17|||format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}}Stayed in Scorpius for the whole year. |- href="International Standard Book Number" |[[Panic of 1907]]{{dts|1907|Oct||format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Left '''Leo''' into Cancer in March 1907. |- href="Special:BookSources/9781942418047" [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]] |[[Wall Street Crash of 1929|Crash of 1929]] |{{dts|1929|Oct|24|format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Stayed in '''Taurus''' for the whole year. |- | href="International Standard Book Number" |[[Kennedy Slide of 1962]] | href="Special:BookSources/9780866900454" |{{dts|1962|05|28|format=dmy}}{{flagicon|USA}}Stayed in '''Leo''' for the whole year. |- href="International Standard Book Number" |Brazilian Markets Crash of 1971 | href="Special:BookSources/9780892546404" |{{dts|1971|July||format=dmy}}{{flagicon|Brazil}}Stayed in '''Aquarius''' for the whole year.[[Souk Al-Manakh stock market crash]]{{dts|1982|Aug|||format=dmy}}{{flagicon|Kuwait}}Stayed in '''Leo''' for the whole year. Rio de Janeiro Stock Exchange Crash{{dts|1989|June||format=dmy}}{{flagicon|Brazil}}Left '''Taurus''' into Aries in May 1989. |- | href="International Standard Book Number" |[[Friday the 13th mini-crash]] | href="Special:BookSources/9781105350078" |{{dts|1989|Oct|13|format=dmy}}{{flagicon|USA}}Left '''Taurus''' into Aries in May 1989. |- href="Special:BookSources/9780787305376"[[Early 1990s recession]] |[[Early 1990s recession]] |{{dts|1990|July||format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Stayed in '''Aquarius''' for the almost whole year.[[Japanese asset price bubble]]{{dts|1991|||format=dmy}}{{flagicon|Japan}}Left '''Aquarius''' in December 1990 and stayed in Capricorn in 1991.[[1998 Russian financial crisis]]{{dts|1998|Aug|17|format=dmy}}{{flagicon|Russia}}Left Virgo into '''Leo''' in September 1998. |- |[[Dot-com bubble]] |{{dts|2000|March|10|format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Left '''Leo''' into Cancer in March 2000. |- |[[United States bear market of 2007–09]] |{{dts|2007|Oct|11|format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Left Pisces into '''Aquarius''' in January 2008. |- |[[2015–16 stock market selloff]] |{{dts|2015|August|18|format=dmy}} |{{flagicon|USA}} |Left Virgo into '''Leo''' in April 2017. |} === Aspects and positions of major planets === [[File:Keplers trigon.jpg|thumb|The Jupiter-Saturn conjunction, as depicted in the Kepler’s trigon here, is one of the key factors in McWhirter’s system.]] McWhirter also lists several secondary factors which tend to raise or depress business, mostly related to aspects of major planets like [[Jupiter]], [[Saturn]], [[Uranus]], [[Neptune]] and [[Pluto]]: {| class="wikitable" ! !Favourable !Unfavourable |- |North Node aspects |Conjunction with Jupiter |Conjunction, opposition, square with Saturn or Uranus |- |Jupiter aspects |Conjunction, trine, sextile with Saturn or Uranus |N/A |- |Saturn-Uranus aspects |Trine, sexile, semi-sextile |Conjunction, opposition, square, semi-square |- |Planet(s) in Gemini |Jupiter, North Node |Saturn, Uranus{{Cite book|title=The Key to Speculation on the New York Stock Exchange|last=Gillen|first=Jack|publisher=American Federation of Astrology|year=2009|isbn=9780866905947|location=|pages=}} |- |Planet(s) in Cancer |Jupiter |N/A |- |Aspects to Pluto |Conjunction, trine, sextile |Opposition, square, semi-square |} === The NYSE natal chart === McWhirter maintained that one should pay attention when a planet moves to 14° [[Cancer (astrology)|Cancer]] (104°) and 24° [[Pisces (astrology)|Pisces]] (354°), because these places are where the [[Ascendant]] and [[Midheaven]] were when the [[New York Stock Exchange]] (NYSE) was initiated by an [[Buttonwood Agreement|agreement]] on 17 May 1792,{{Cite book|title=The London and New York Stock Exchanges 1850-1914|last=Michie|first=Ranald|publisher=Routledge|year=2011|isbn=9781136736681|location=Oxon, UK|pages=}} though only after rectifying the exact time to 7:52 am. Similarly, since the tenth house of the NYSE chart was in [[Pisces (astrology)|Pisces]] and [[Aries (astrology)|Aries]], which are ruled by [[Neptune]] and [[Mars]] respectively, she also thought that aspects to these two planets are important. === New moon analysis === In a shorter timeframe, McWhirter uses the new moon for timing market turns. The key idea is that she would pay attention to planets which make an astrological aspect to the new moon, and watch them as the moon passes through them later.{{Cite book|title=The Vedic Code of Stocks- 2012 Monthly Predictions|last=Charran|first=Ram|publisher=Heendu Learning|year=2011|isbn=9781105350078|location=|pages=}} == Comparison with W. D. Gann == === Identity suspicion === M. G. Bucholtz suspects that “Louise McWhirter” is not the author’s real name. His reason is that he comes across no other books by McWhirter and finds no other sources mentioning this person. He believes that the real identity of Louise McWhirter was famous market forecaster [[William Delbert Gann|W. D. Gann]], whom Bucholtz believes used similar techniques in market predictions. According to Pythagorean numerology, the names “W. D. Gann” and “Louise McWhirter” share the same numerological root of “9”.{{Cite book|title=The Science of Numerology Through the Law of Vibration|last=Laurie|first=John C.|publisher=Health Research Books|year=1959|isbn=9780787305376|location=Pomeroy, WA|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=The ancient science of numbers. The practical application of its principles in the attainment of health, success, and happiness|last=Clement|first=Luo|publisher=Roger brothers|year=1908|isbn=9781298455536|location=New York: NY|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=Numerology: Or, What Pythagoras Wrought|last=Dudley|first=Underwood|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1997|isbn=9780883855249|location=Cambridge, UK|pages=}} It is possibly not an coincidence, since some people believe that Gann was an numerologist.{{Cite book|title=W. D. Gann: Divination by Mathematics|last=Awodele|first=|publisher=Bekh, LLC|year=2013|isbn=9780615833439|location=Union: KY|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=The Heretics of Finance: Conversations with Leading Practitioners of Technical Analysis|last=Lo|first=Andrew W.|last2=Hasanhodzic|first2=Jasmina|publisher=Bloomberg Press|year=2010|isbn=9780470885369|location=New York: NY|pages=}} === Gann’s financial timetable === One of the biggest connection between McWhirter and Gann is that McWhirter’s Nodal cycle theory is very similar to Gann’s “financial timetable”.{{Cite book|title=Collected Writings of W.D. Gann|last=Gann|first=William Delbert|publisher=Sacred Science Institute|year=2015|isbn=9781942418085|volume=4|location=|pages=}} It is timetable with alternating 18- and 19-year cycle, which mimics the Nodal cycle very closely. Like McWhirter’s theory, Gann also found that the stock market follows a rhythm of 18–19 years.{{Cite book|title=The 17.6 Year Stock Market Cycle: Connecting the Panics of 1929, 1987, 2000 and 2007|last=Balenthiran|first=Kerry|publisher=Harriman House Limited|year=2013|isbn=9780857193094|location=|pages=}} Here is a modernised example of the table: {| class="wikitable" - ! rowspan="2" |Major Low |1990 |2008 |2027 |2045 |- |1991 |2009 |2028 |2046 |- ! rowspan="3" |Booming |1992 |2010 |2029 |2047 |- |1993 |2011 |2030 |2048 |- |1994 |2012 |2031 |2049 |- ! rowspan="2" |Major High |1995 |2013 |2032 |2050 |- |1996 |2014 |2033 |2051 |- ! rowspan="2" |Correction |1997 |2015 |2034 |2052 |- |1998 |2016 |2035 |2053 |- ! rowspan="2" |Major Top |1999 |2017 |2036 |2054 |- |2000 |2018 |2037 |2055 |- ! rowspan="2" |Big Crash |2001 |2019 |2038 |2056 |- |2002 |2020 |2039 |2057 |- ! rowspan="2" |Major Low |2003 |2021 |2040 |2058 |- |2004 |2022 |2041 |2059 |- ! rowspan="2" |Major High |2005 |2023 |2042 |2060 |- |2006 |2024 |2043 |2061 |- ! rowspan="2" |Major Top |2007 |2025 |2044 |2062 |- | -- |2026 | -- |2063 |} == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McWhirter, Louise}} [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Possibly living people]] [[Category:Astrology]]

'''Mahikari''' is a [[Japan]]ese [[new religious movement]] ([[Japanese new religions|shinshūkyō]]) that was founded in 1959 by [[Yoshikazu Okada]] (岡田 良一) (1901–1974). The word "Mahikari" means "True (真, ma) Light (光, hikari)" in [[Japanese language|Japanese]].<ref>{{harvnb|Yasaka|1999|p=25}}</ref>
==Foundation== This organization was founded based on a revelation dated February 27, 1959. Okada said that this revelation related to the mission of bringing purification to the world and humanity.<ref>{{harvnb|McVeigh, Brian|1992|p=41}}</ref> Thus, he founded the organization, "L.H. Yokoshi Tomo no Kai" (陽光子友乃会 – Association of Positive People [children] of Light). In 1963, he registered the organization under the name "Sekai Mahikari Bunmei Kyodan" (World Divine Light Organization).
==Okada's world view== Okada claimed that the revelation was from the Creator God, Mioya Motosu Mahikari Omikami ("Great Parent, Great Origin, True Light, Great God"), or simply, "Su (主, Lord) God." He mentioned his role to pioneer the introduction of the art of True Light, a method of spiritual purification that cleanses the spirit, mind, and body, and serves as an expedient to attaining happiness.
Okada claimed that the world was approaching a time of great upheaval, "baptism by fire," in which humanity will be cleansed through abnormal weather, social turmoil, and so on. He emphasized that humanity had entered this period in earnest from January 1, 1962. Okada said an increase in what he called the spiritual energy of fire would result in phenomena such as flooding, cold snaps, and potable water would becoming increasingly scarce. He said humankind needed to work hastily to develop techniques of turning sea water into drinkable water.
The holy scriptures of Mahikari consist of ''The Holy Words'' (''Goseigen'') and ''The Yōkōshi Prayer Book'' (''Norigotoshū'').
==Religious organization with similarities==
===Tenrikyo=== [[Tenrikyo]] was founded by Miki Nakayama (1798–1886). Its name means “Heavenly Wisdom” ("tenri" means heavenly wisdom and "kyo" means teaching or religion). During a healing ceremony, Miki reportedly entered a trance and said, “I am the True and Original God. I have been predestined to reside here. I have descended from Heaven to save all human beings, and I want to take Miki as the Shrine of God and the mediatrix between God and men.”
===Konkokyo=== [[Konkokyo]], which may be translated as “Golden Light,” was founded by Bunjiro Kawate (1814–1883) in 1859. "[Kawate] found Parent of all men, the Parent-God of the Universe, who revealed himself ... as Tenchi-Kane-no-kami. It was on November the 15th of 1859 that the words of God came upon the Founder, calling him to the sacred mission of saving men, and revealing at the same time that the prosperity of mankind is the ultimate purpose of the Parent-God of the Universe, and that without the realization of that purpose God Himself is morally imperfect."<ref>{{harvnb|Thomsen|1963|p=70.}}</ref>
===Oomoto=== [[Oomoto]], which means “The Teaching of the Great Origin,” was founded in 1892 by [[Nao Deguchi]] (1836–1918). She claimed she had a visitation of a supernatural entity bestowing a mission on her to save humankind, that the origin was one, that mankind must return to that origin, and that humankind faced a great upheaval. Oomoto was promoted as the catalyst to unite all religions. Deguchi claimed to receive revelations from her god-deity, which she wrote down as the [[Ofudesaki (Oomoto)|Ofudesaki]], "From the Tip of the Brush," and used a healing method called ''Miteshiro'' (honorable hand-substitute) to drive out possessing spirits.
===Sekai Kyūsei Kyō=== [[Church of World Messianity|Sekai Kyūsei Kyō]] (世界救世教 – Church of World Messianity) was founded by [[Mokichi Okada]] (1882–1955). In June 1920, he joined Oomoto. Okada was a teacher in an Oomoto church in Tokyo in 1934 when he started using a process different from the official Oomoto healing method and was expelled.
Some of the practices practiced by devotees of Sekai Kyūsei Kyō are very similar to those practiced by Mahikari members. For example, the practise of ''Johrei'' (Purification of the Spirit), the imagined energy radiating from the hand, is similar to ''Mahikari no waza'' (True Light), and the ''Ohikari'', the pendant worn around the neck by members of Sekai Kyusei Kyo, is similar in concept to the ''Omitama'' pendant worn around the neck by Mahikari members.<ref>{{harvnb|McVeigh, Brian|1992|p=41.}} "The notion of a divine energy administered through the hand can be found in other New Religions. In Omoto there is the belief in shinki / reiki (divine spirit) that is radiated in a ritual called miteshiro (divine hand-substitute). Sekai Kyiiseikyb's hikari (light) is given in a ritual called jorei (spirit cleaning). Jorei is very similar to Mahikari's okijome, as is Omoto's miteshiro."</ref>
===Other Influences upon Yoshikazu Okada===
====''Hikari wa tōhō yori'' (Light from the East)==== "In a collection of [Okada's] sermons we find a chapter entitled “Light from the East,” which explains that the founders of the world’s great religions realized their teachings could not reveal the ultimate truth, and knew that such the truth would eventually come from the East. <ref>{{harvnb|Knecht, Peter|1995|p=337}}</ref>
====Kojiki, Record of Ancient Matters==== "Much earlier Mahikari mythology is attributed to the [[Kojiki]], Records of Ancient Matters, which was written circa 712 CE. Though the Kojiki is a depository of Shinto myths, it is well known to scholars as a “late compilation in which political considerations and specifically Chinese conceptions intrude themselves almost everywhere.” Mahikari utilizes many of the mythological deities found in the Kojiki but focuses on the Su God who personally chose Okada as his savior." <ref>{{harvnb|Weston, Erin Leigh|2002|p=45}}</ref>
==Mahikari organizations== The following organizations (listed in order of establishment date) are ''Shinshūkyō'' that were influenced by the world-view and practices of Yoshikazu Okada:
* 1959 : "L.H. Yokoshi Tomo no Kai" (Company of Sun Light Children) – name later changed to Sekai Mahikari Bunmei Kyodan * 1963 : "Sekai Mahikari Bunmei Kyodan" – nominal membership – 50,000 to 100,000 worldwide (2007) * 1974 : "Shin Yu Gen Kyu Sei Mahikari Kyodan" * 1978 : "[[Sukyo Mahikari]]" (Japan) – nominal membership – 1,000,000+ worldwide (2009) * 1978–1979 : "The Light Center" ([[Belgium]]) * 1980 : "Suhikari Koha Sekai Shindan" – nominal membership – 4,500 (2007) * 1984 : "Yokoshi Tomo No Kai" ([[Singapore]])
===Sekai Mahikari Bunmei Kyodan=== Sekai Mahikari Bunmei Kyodan (World Divine Light Organization) is the name of an independent organization founded by [[Yoshikazu Okada]] in 1959 as "Yokoshi Tomo no Kai" (Association of Positive People [children] of Light). Okada was the organization's first "Holy Master" (Holy name: ''Seio, Kotama''). After Okada's death on June 23, 1974, the Reverend Seiho Sakae Sekiguchi (1909–1994) became the second "Holy Master" of the organization by "divine degree". During his leadership, the organization established the "Su-za World Main Shrine" in [[Mount Amagi]] on the [[Izu Peninsula]] on August 23, 1987. On January 3, 1994, the Reverend Seisho (Katsutoshi Sekiguchi (1939–) became the third "Holy Master" of the organization, also by "divine degree".
===Sukyo Mahikari=== [[Sukyo Mahikari]] (崇教真光) is the name of an independent organization founded by Keishu Okada in 1978, the adopted daughter of [[Yoshikazu Okada]], following his death and the subsequent legal dispute over leadership of Sekai Mahikari Bunmei Kyodan. The Sukyo Mahikari World headquarters is located at the "World Shrine" to the Creator God, which was completed in [[Takayama, Gifu|Takayama City]], [[Gifu Prefecture]], in 1984. The Takayama site also includes the [http://h-am.jp/ Hikaru Museum], a museum opened in 1999 that depicts the life and world-view of Mr. Okada and the Sukyo Mahikari organization.
===Suhikari Kōha Sekai Shindan=== Suhikari Kōha Sekai Shindan was founded in 1980 by the [[spiritualist]] and [[manga]] artist Kuroda Minoru (1928– ).<ref>{{harvnb|Inoue, Nobutaka|1991}} Kuroda is a known for his themes of ghost stories or the curses of spirits. His cartoons are popular especially among junior and senior high school girls. Since initiating his religious activities, Kuroda has used his cartoon drawings as a medium of missionary activities. He is also engaged in counseling young people.</ref> Kuroda had been a follower of [[Yoshikazu Okada]] and Sekai Mahikari Bunmei Kyōdan. After Okada's death, Kuroda left that organization and, after receiving a [[revelation]], established the "Shūkyō Dantai Kōrin" in 1980, registering the group as an independent religious body under the Religious Corporations Law (Shūkyō Hōjinhō). In 1984 the group assumed its current name. Its headquarters are in Hachiōji City, Tokyo.

{{Infobox musical composition | name = ''Messiah'' Part III | image = Unionskirche Idstein Revelation.jpg | caption = "Worthy is the Lamb", ceiling of [[Unionskirche, Idstein]], ca. 1670 | composer = [[George Frideric Handel]] | year = {{Start date|1741}} | genre = [[Oratorio]] | period = [[Baroque music|Baroque]] | movements = 9 in four scenes | text = [[Charles Jennens]], a compilation from the [[Authorized King James Version|King James Bible]] and the [[Book of Common Prayer]] | composed = {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|1741|08|22|df=y}}|end_date={{End date|1741|09|14|df=y}}|location=London}} | vocal = [[SATB|{{abbr|SATB|soprano, alto, tenor and bass}}]] choir and solo | instrumental = {{Flatlist| * 2 [[trumpet]]s * [[timpani]] * 2 [[oboe]]s * 2 [[violin]]s * [[viola]] * [[basso continuo]] }} }} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Messiah'' Part III}} '''''[[Messiah (Handel)|Messiah]]''''' ([[Händel-Werke-Verzeichnis|HWV]] 56), the English-language [[oratorio]] composed by [[George Frideric Handel]] in 1741, is [[Structure of Handel's Messiah|structured]] in three parts. This listing covers '''Part III''' in a table and comments on individual movements, reflecting the relation of the musical setting to the text. [[Messiah Part I|Part I]] begins with the prophecy of the [[Messiah#Christianity|Messiah]] and his [[Nativity of Jesus|birth]], shows the [[annunciation to the shepherds]] as a scene from the [[Gospel of Luke]], and reflects the Messiah's deeds on Earth. [[Messiah Part II|Part II]] covers the [[Passion (Christianity)|Passion]], death, resurrection, [[Ascension of Jesus|ascension]], and the later spreading of the Gospel. Part III concentrates on [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]]'s teaching of the [[1 Corinthians 15#Resurrection of the dead: 12-58|resurrection of the dead]] and Christ's [[Book of Revelation#Outline|glorification in heaven]]. {{TOC limit|3}} == Messiah, the oratorio == The [[libretto]] by [[Charles Jennens]] is entirely drawn from the Bible, mostly from the [[Authorized King James Version|King James Bible]], whereas several [[psalms]] are taken from the [[Book of Common Prayer]].{{r|Vickers}}{{r|Powell 2009}} The librettist commented: "... the Subject excells every other Subject. The Subject is Messiah ...".{{r|Heighes 1997}} ''Messiah'' differs from Handel's other oratorios by telling no story, instead offering reflections on different aspects of the Christian [[Messiah#Christianity|Messiah]]. [[Christopher Hogwood]] comments: {{quote | ''Messiah'' is not a typical Handel oratorio; there are no named characters, as are usually found in Handel’s setting of the Old Testament stories, possibly to avoid charges of blasphemy. It is a meditation rather than a drama of personalities, lyrical in method; the narration of the story is carried on by implication, and there is no dialogue. | [[Christopher Hogwood]]{{r|Block 2001}} }} === Structure and concept === {{main|Structure of Handel's Messiah}} The oratorio's structure follows the [[liturgical year]]; Part I corresponding with [[Advent]], Christmas and the life of Jesus, Part II with [[Lent]], Easter, [[Feast of the Ascension|Ascension]] and [[Pentecost]], Part III with the end of the church year, dealing with the end of time, the [[1 Corinthians 15#Resurrection of the dead: 12-58|Resurrection of the dead]] and Christ's [[Book of Revelation#Outline|glorification in heaven]]. The sources are drawn mostly from the [[Old Testament]].{{r|Powell 2009}} Even the birth and death of Jesus are told in the words of the prophet [[Isaiah]], the most prominent source of the libretto. The only true scene of the oratorio is taken from the [[Gospel of Luke]], the [[annunciation to the shepherds]].{{r|Luckett 1992}} The imagery of shepherd and lamb features prominently, in the aria "He shall feed His flock like a shepherd", the only extended piece to talk about the Messiah on earth, in the opening of Part II, "Behold the Lamb of God", in the chorus "All we like sheep", and in the closing chorus of the work, "Worthy is the Lamb". Occasionally verses from different biblical sources are combined in one movement, but more often a coherent text section is set in different consecutive movements, such as the first "[[Structure of Handel's Messiah#Scenes|scene]]", the annunciation of [[Christian salvation]], as a sequence of three movements, [[recitative]], [[aria]] and [[Choir|chorus]]. === Music === When Handel composed ''Messiah'' in London, he was already a successful and experienced composer of Italian operas. He had started in 1713 to also compose sacred music on English texts, such as the ''[[Utrecht Te Deum and Jubilate]]''. He set many [[oratorio]]s on English [[Libretto|libretti]]. In ''Messiah'' he used practically the same musical means as for those works, namely a structure based on chorus and solo singing. Only a few movements are a [[duet]] or a combination of solo and chorus. The solos are typically a combination of recitative and aria. The arias are called Air or Song, some of them have [[da capo]] form, but rarely in a strict sense, repeating a first section after a sometimes contrasting middle section. Handel finds various ways to use the format freely, in order to convey the text. The movements marked "Recitative" (Rec.) are "secco", only accompanied by the [[Figured bass#Basso continuo|basso continuo]]. Recitatives marked "Accompagnato" (Acc.) are accompanied by additional string instruments. Handel uses four voice parts in both solo and chorus, [[soprano]] (S), [[alto]] (A), [[tenor]] (T) and [[Bass (voice type)|bass]] (B). Only once is the chorus divided in an upper chorus and a lower chorus, it is [[SATB]] otherwise. The orchestra scoring is simple: [[oboe]]s, [[String instrument|strings]] and basso continuo of [[harpsichord]], [[violoncello]], [[violone]] and [[bassoon]]. Two trumpets and [[timpani]] highlight selected movements, such as the closing movements of Part II, ''Hallelujah''. Handel uses a [[cantus firmus]] on long repeated notes especially to illustrate God's speech and majesty, such as "King of Kings" in the Hallelujah chorus.{{r|Burrows 1991}} === General notes === The following table is organized by movement numbers. There are two major systems of numbering the movements of ''Messiah'': the historic [[Novello & Co|Novello]] edition of 1959 (which is based on earlier editions and contains 53 movements), and the [[Bärenreiter]] edition of 1965 in the [[Hallische Händel-Ausgabe]]. Not counting some short recitatives as separate movements, there are therefore 47 movements. In the table below, the Novello number (Nov) is given first and is the index for the notes to individual movements in the "movements" section, then the Bärenreiter number (Bär). To emphasise the movements in which the oboes (ob) and the rarely used trumpets (tr) and timpani (ti) play, the summary below does not mention the regular basso continuo and the strings in movements. Details on the development of [[Key signature|key]]s, different [[tempo]] markings [[Time signature|time]]s within a movement are given in notes on the individual movements. Movements originally in Italian (It) are indicated in the Source column, however the exact origin is supplied in the notes on the movement. == Part III == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Nov ! Bär ! Title / First line ! Form ! Tempo marking ! Scoring ! Time ! Key ! Allegro moderato || trumpet timpani oboe || {{music|common-time}} || D major |} == Part III movements == === Scene 1 === [[Structure of Handel's Messiah#Scenes|Scene 1]] tells in an aria and a chorus of the resurrection, based on the Messianic anticipation in the [[Book of Job#In Christianity|Book of Job]] ({{sourcetext | source = Bible | version = King James | book = Job | chapter = 19 | verse = 25 | range = –26 }}) and [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]]'s teaching in his first epistle to the [[1 Corinthians 15#Resurrection of the dead: 12-58|Corinthians]] ({{sourcetext | source = Bible | version = King James | book = 1 Corinthians | chapter = 15 | verse = 20 | range = –22 }}). ==== 45 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 46. I know that my Redeemer liveth.ogg|title=''I know that my redeemer liveth''|description=1953: [[Hermann Scherchen]] directing the [[London Symphony Orchestra]] and [[London Philharmonic Choir]]; Margaret Ritchie, soprano; Constance Schacklock, contralto; William Herbert, tenor; Richard Standen, bass; Frederick Jackson, chorus master; Thomas Matthews, violin; George Eskdale, trumpet.}} '''I know that my Redeemer liveth''' The Air for soprano "I know that my Redeemer liveth" draws from both Job and Paul. It begins with the "ascending [[Perfect fourth|fourth]]", a signal observed by musicologist Rudolf Steglich as a unifying motif of the oratorio,{{r|Luckett 1992}} on the words "I know", repeated almost every time these words appear again. "For now is Christ risen" is pictured in a steadily rising melody of more than an [[octave]]. ==== 46 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 47. Since by man came death.ogg|title=''Since by man came death''|description=(see above)}} '''Since by man came death''' The text for the chorus "Since by man came death" continues Paul's thoughts, juxtaposing death and resurrection twice. Consequently, Handel twice uses a Grave [[a cappella]] setting in [[A minor]] with [[Chromatic scale|chromatic]] lines, opposed to an Allegro with orchestra in [[C major]] in most simple harmony, switching back and forth between these extremes. === Scene 2 === [[Structure of Handel's Messiah#Scenes|Scene 2]] deals with Paul's teachings on the [[1 Corinthians 15#Resurrection of the body: 35-58|Resurrection of the body]] on the [[Day of Judgement]], as written in his First Epistle to the Corinthians. Accompagnato and Air share three verses, {{sourcetext | source = Bible | version = King James | book = 1 Corinthians | chapter = 15 | verse = 51 | range = –53 }}. Handel breaks the text in the middle of the second verse, to open the aria with the musical idea "the trumpet shall sound". The image, first found in Exodus 19, pictures a courtly herald who blew the trumpet as a signal that the king was about to enter the throne room, a signal to stand in his honour.{{r|Block 2001}} The passage from 1 Corinthians 15 was also chosen by Johannes Brahms for ''[[A German Requiem (Brahms)|Ein deutsches Requiem]]'', but in the German translation of the Bible the instrument is a [[trombone]]. ==== 47 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 48. Behold, I tell you a mystery.ogg|title=''Behold, I tell you a mystery''|description=(see above)}} '''Behold, I tell you a mystery''' "Behold, I tell you a mystery" is rendered as a bass accompagnato in [[D major]]. Towards the end, [[Motif (music)|motif]]s like trumpet signals appear in the strings even before the last words "at the last trumpet". ==== 48 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 49. The trumpet shall sound.ogg|title=''The trumpet shall sound''|description=(see above)}} '''The trumpet shall sound''' The Air for bass "The trumpet shall sound", marked "Pomposo, ma non allegro", is a [[da capo aria]]. In the work's only instrumental solo, the trumpet provides motifs which the bass picks up. In "and we shall be changed", the word "changed" is treated in inventive ever-changing [[melisma]]s of up to six measures. In the middle section, the word "immortality" is expressed in a lively melisma of first eight, then nine measures. === Scene 3 === [[Structure of Handel's Messiah#Scenes|Scene 3]] first continues the text of Scene 2 ({{sourcetext | source = Bible | version = King James | book = 1 Corinthians | chapter = 15 | verse = 54 | range = –57 }}), presented in recitative, duet and chorus, and ends with an Air on Paul's [[Epistle to the Romans#Assurance of salvation (Rom 5-8,9-11)|Assurance of salvation]], as written in the Epistle to the Romans, {{sourcetext | source = Bible | version = King James | book = Romans | chapter = 8 | verse = 31 | range = ,33–34 }}. ==== 49 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 50. Then shall be brought to pass.ogg|title=''Then shall be brought to pass''|description=(see above)}} '''Then shall be brought to pass''' An alto recitative delivers "Then shall be brought to pass", ending on "death is swallow'd up in victory". ==== 50 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 51. O death, where is thy sting.ogg|title=''O death, where is thy sting?''|description=(see above)}} '''O death, where is thy sting?''' "O death, where is thy sting?" is sung as a [[duet]] in [[E flat major]] of alto and tenor on a [[walking bass]] of the continuo, without strings. The movement is based on the duet for soprano and alto "Se tu non lasci amore" (HWV 193, 1722).{{r|compositionslist}} Such a movement would remind the London listeners of love duets concluding operas, such as the final scene of "[[Giulio Cesare in Egitto|Giulio Cesare]]."{{r|Keates 2007}} ==== 51 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 52. But thanks be to God.ogg|title=''But thanks be to God''|description=(see above)}} '''But thanks be to God''' The chorus answers in the same key and tempo "But thanks be to God". ==== 52 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 53. If God be for us, who can be against us.ogg|title=''If God be for us, who can be against us''|description=(see above)}} '''If God be for us, who can be against us''' The scene closes with the assurance "If God be for us, who can be against us". As a contrast to the following choral conclusion of the oratorio, it is sung by the soprano. Towards the end, Handel quotes the characteristic intervals beginning [[Martin Luther]]'s [[chorale]] ''[[Aus tiefer Not schrei ich zu dir]]'' several times, leading into the final chorus. === Scene 4 === [[Structure of Handel's Messiah#Scenes|Scene 4]] closes the work by visionary verses from the Book of Revelation, [[Book of Revelation#Outline|The creatures in heaven give praise]] ({{sourcetext | source = Bible | version = King James | book = Revelation | chapter = 5 | verse = 12 | range = –13 }}), affirmed by an extended [[Amen]]. ==== 53 ==== {{Listen|type=music|filename=Handel - Messiah, Part 3 (Scherchen) - 54. Worthy is the Lamb. Amen.ogg|title=''Worthy is the Lamb that was slain, Amen.''|description=(see above)}} [[File:Worthy-is-the-lamb.jpg|thumb|300px|Beginning of "Worthy is the Lamb", ending Part III, in Handel's manuscript]] '''Worthy is the Lamb that was slain''' The chorus, with the full orchestra including trumpets and timpani, proclaims in a solemn Largo "Worthy is the Lamb that was slain", and continues Andante "to receive power – and riches, – and wisdom, – and strength, – and honour, – and glory, – and blessing". The sequence of Largo and Andante is repeated, but not exactly the same music. A fugue carries the words "Blessing and honour, glory and pow'r be unto him". The men's voices and the continuo begin in [[unison]], the simple theme rises to a note which is repeated nine times and falls back, reminiscent of the repeated notes in "[[Messiah Part I#4|For the mouth of the Lord hath spoken it]]" and "[[Hallelujah chorus|King of Kings]]". Several countersubjects add life and texture, gradually more instruments take part in the development on "for ever – and ever". These words are rendered in short downward runs, but then also in the same rhythm as in the [[Hallelujah chorus]], and finally broadened to Adagio. The "Amen" begins again simply in the bass and continuo. An intricate melody rises in four measures and one octave. Every other voice, tenor, alto, soprano, also sings the theme once. Rather unexpectedly, a solo violin plays the theme, first unsupported, then assisted by a continuo entrance of the theme, interrupted by a choral four-part setting with the theme in the bass. After two more instrumental measures, a four-part-setting develops to imitation and [[counterpoint]] of more and more independent voices, ending on a rest of a full measure. Finally, Amen is repeated two more times, Adagio. A contemporary critic, conditioned by John Brown who objected to operatic features in oratorios such as recitatives, long ritornellos, and ornamented vocal lines, commented on Handel's display of musical inventiveness and "contrapuntal skill"{{r|Keates 2007}}: "The fugue too, on Amen, is entirely absurd, and without reason: at most, Amen is only a devout fiat, and ought never, therefore, to have been frittered, as it is, by endless divisions on A— and afterwards men."{{r|Heighes 1997}} But Handel's first biographer, [[John Mainwaring]], wrote in 1760 that this conclusion revealed the composer "rising still higher" than in "that vast effort of genius, the Hallelujah chorus".{{r|Luckett 1992}} [[Christopher Hogwood]] comments: "the entry of the trumpets marks the final storming of heaven".{{r|Hogwood 1991}} [[Daniel I. Block]] summarized in 1997: "... in this piece we see the remarkable confluence of Hebrew theology and biblical truth, Italian operatic genius, English class, and German piety."{{r|Block 2001}} == See also == {{Wikisource|Messiah}} * [[Messiah (Handel)|''Messiah'' (Handel)]] * [[Structure of Handel's Messiah|Structure of Handel's ''Messiah'']] * [[Messiah Part I|''Messiah'' Part I]] * [[Messiah Part II|''Messiah'' Part II]] == References == {{reflist | colwidth = 30em | refs = {{cite web |last = Vickers |first = David |title = Messiah (HWV 56) "A Sacred Oratorio" |publisher = gfhandel.org |url = http://www.gfhandel.org/messiah.htm |accessdate = 14 July 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110717031156/http://www.gfhandel.org/messiah.htm |archivedate = 17 July 2011 |df = }} {{cite web | last = Powell | first = David R. | year = 2009 | title = The Bible and Handel's Messiah: Some Sources on Their Relation and Use | publisher = Theological Librarianship, An Online Journal of the American Theological Library Association | work = journal.atla.com | url = https://journal.atla.com/ojs/index.php/theolib/article/viewFile/121/394 | accessdate = 8 July 2011 }} {{cite web | last = Heighes | first = Simon | year = 1997 | title = George Frideric Handel (1685–1759) / Messiah.
