{{use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{Redirect|Sadguru|Sadguru (disambiguation)}} '''Satguru''' ({{lang-sa|सद्गुरू}}), or '''sadguru''', means the true [[guru]]. However the term is distinguished from other forms of gurus, such as musical instructors, scriptural teachers, parents, and so on. The satguru is a title given specifically only to an enlightened [[rishi]] or [[saint]] whose life's purpose is to guide the initiated ''[[Guru-shishya tradition|shishya]]'' on the spiritual path, the summation of which is the realization of the [[Self (spirituality)|Self]] through realization of [[God]]. A Satguru has some special characteristics that are not found in any other types of Spiritual Guru. The words 'Sant' and 'Satguru' firstly came into existence from the spiritual ideology of “Sant Samrat Satguru Kabir Sahib” in the 15th century. Kabir Sahib says "Satpurush Ko Jansi, Tiska Satguru Naam|" meaning the one who has seen the supreme lord of truth- Satya Purush is Satguru.'Kabir Sagara' "Devi dewal jagat mein, kotik poojey koye. Satguru ki pooja kiye, sabb ki pooja hoye".Kabir Sagara Kabir Sahib says Worship of Satguru includes in it worship of all deities. In other words, Satguru is physical form of God (Sat Pursh). == Ancient and traditional sources == The recommendation says that the first and the foremost qualification of the True Master (Satguru) is that he must have known the True Lord ([[God]]) himself.[[Adi Granth]]: 286 In one of [[Kabir]]'s songsLVI I. 68. bhâi kôî satguru sant kahâwaî the satguru is described as the real [[sadhu]]:
He is the real Sadhu, who can reveal the form of the Formless to the vision of these eyes; Who teaches the simple way of attaining Him, that is other than rites or ceremonies; Who does not make you close the doors, and hold the breath, and renounce the world; Who makes you perceive the Supreme Spirit wherever the mind attaches itself; Who teaches you to be still in the midst of all your activities. Ever immersed in bliss, having no fear in his mind, he keeps the spirit of union in the midst of all enjoyments. The infinite dwelling of the Infinite Being is everywhere: in earth, water, sky, and air; Firm as the thunderbolt, the seat of the seeker is established above the void. He who is within is without: I see Him and none else.''Songs of Kabir'' LVI, I. 68 - Translated by [[Rabindranath Tagore]] New York, The Macmillan Company (1915)
[[Vasistha]], [[Rama]]'s guru, was the satguru in the [[Treta yuga]]. Swami Shankar Purushottam Tirtha quotes the ''[[Yoga Vasistha]]'':
A real preceptor is one who can produce blissful sensation in the body of the disciple by their sight, touch, or instructions.{{cite book | last = Tirtha | first = Swami Shankar Purushottam | authorlink = Swami Shankar Purushottam Tirtha | coauthors = | title = Yoga Vani: Instructions for the Attainment of Siddhayoga | publisher = Sat Yuga Press | year = 1992 | location = New York | pages = 27 | doi = | id = | isbn = }}
According to [[Sivaya Subramuniyaswami]], a Hindu satguru is always a ''[[sannyasa|sannyasin]]'', an unmarried renunciate,Subramuniyaswami, Satguru Sivaya. ''Living with Siva'', [http://www.himalayanacademy.com/resources/books/lws/lws_glossary_S-Z.html glossary]. Himalayan Academy Publications. {{ISBN|0-945497-98-9}} but not all writers include this stricture.''God Speaks'', Meher Baba, PUB Dodd Meade, 1955, 2nd Ed. pp. 150,158,196, 291 [[Tukaram]], a Hindu satguru, is known to have had a family, and [[Moinuddin Chishti]] also had children. Satguru Kabir had a son, Kamal, who was very devout.''Meher Prabhu'', Bhau Kalchuri, Manifestation, Inc. 1986. p.92 - Footnote 1 In [[Sant Mat]] and [[Advait Mat]], the living Satguru is considered the path to God-realization.Lewis, James R. ''Seeking the Light'', p.62. Mandeville Press, {{ISBN|0-914829-42-4}} [[Meher Baba]] equated worship of the Satguru with worship of God: "Consciously or unconsciously, directly or indirectly, each and every creature, each and every human being — in one form or the other — strives to assert individuality. But when eventually man consciously experiences that he is Infinite, Eternal and Indivisible, then he is fully conscious of his individuality as God, and as such experiences Infinite Knowledge, Infinite Power and Infinite Bliss. Thus Man becomes God, and is recognized as a [[Perfect Master (Meher Baba)|Perfect Master]], Satguru, or [[Qutb|Kutub]]. To worship this Man is to worship God."[[Meher Baba|Baba, Meher]] (2000). [http://www.ambppct.org/meherbaba/Book_Files/POL.pdf ''The Path of Love''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927073028/http://www.ambppct.org/meherbaba/Book_Files/POL.pdf |date=2011-09-27 }}. Myrtle Beach: Sheriar Foundation. pp. 28 - 29. {{ISBN|1-880619-23-7}}. ==See also== * [[Appayya Swamigalu]] * [[Bodhinatha Veylanswami]] * [[Ghasidas]] * [[Guru Ravidas|Ravidas]] * [[Ravidassia religion]] * [[Sant Mat]] * [[Advaita Vedanta]] * [[Ramana Maharshi]] ==References== {{reflist}}{{Sant Mat}} [[Category:Hindu religious leaders| ]]

{{For|village and union council|Seri Bahlol, Mardan}} {{Infobox UNESCO World Heritage Site | WHS = Sahri Bahlol | image = Seri-Bahlol Showing village view and agriculture land.JPG | image_upright = 1.2 | caption = | location = [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Pakistan]], <!-- make selection: P17 (country) and possibly P131 (administrative subdivision of country) suffice in most cases --> | part_of = Buddhist Ruins of [[Takht-i-Bahi]] and Neighbouring City Remains at Sahr-i-Bahlol | criteria = {{UNESCO WHS type|(iv)}}(iv) | ID = 140-002 | coordinates = {{Coord|34|15|19.71|N|71|57|02.48|E|region:PK_type:landmark|display=title, inline|format=dms}} | year = 1980 | locmapin = Pakistan | map_caption = }} '''Seri Bahlol''', also '''Sahri Bahlol''' ({{lang-ur|{{nq|سری بہلول}}}}), is located near [[Takht-i-Bahi]], about 70 kilometer north-west of [[Peshawar]], [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Pakistan]].
==History== [[File:Gandhara Sahr-i-Bhalol.jpg |thumb|left|Seri Bahlol is at the center of the [[Gandhara]] area.]] Seri Bahlol is a historical place and it has been included in the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage List]] since 1980.<ref name="Unesco">Unesco [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/140/]</ref> The ruins of Seri Bahlol are the remnants of a small ancient fortified town built during the [[Kushan]] period.<ref name="Unesco"/><ref>{{cite book|last1=Katariya|first1=Adesh|title=The Glorious History of Kushana Empire: Kushana Gurjar History|date=2012|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=P7TpDAAAQBAJ&pg=RA1-PT47&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref> The city was protected during the time of [[John Marshall (archaeologist)|John Marshall]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Conserving Fortified Heritage: The Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Fortifications and World Heritage|date=2016|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|isbn=9781443896375|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=8CFUDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA87&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref>
It contains the remains of [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]], which have not been properly excavated. Antiques such as statues, coins, utensils and jewellery are commonly found.<ref>Hassan Dani, Dr: The Peshawar</ref> The local people continue illegal excavation in their homes and land, damaging the historical monuments. Some of the local dealers of antiques misguide the local population and instigate them to involve in illegal excavation. It requires national and international attention in order to reserve the remnants at Seri Bahlol.<ref name="Unesco"/>
The word "Seri Bahlol" has been explained by various people in different ways. The local people, however, explains that this is a combination of two [[Hindi]] words "Sheri" means Sir and "Bahlol" the name of a prominent political and religious leader of the area. However, the name is not as old as the village Seri Bahlol. The village is located on a hillock protected by a well sophisticated stone wall which was constructed under the [[Kushans]].<ref name="Unesco"/> The wall is damaged in several places, but it is still visible in many places. The village is surrounded by fertile land where local people practice agriculture. For the last few years, the rapid population growth has engulfed the agriculture land which is a risk for food security.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Seri Bahlol-Agriculture Land-1.jpg|A farmer applying pesticides to his crop File:Seri-Bahlol-General view-2.jpg|A view of the village Sahri-Bahlol excavations 1911-1912.jpg|Excavations in 1911-1912. File:024 Bodhisattva Meditating, 1c Sahr-i-Bahlol (9218660777).jpg|Meditating [[Bodhisattva]]. Schist. Sahr-i-Bahlol. [[Patna Museum]] 39. Ordination of Nanda-2nd century CE-Sahri Bahlol-Gandhara Gallery- Indian Museum- Kolkata.-G11-A23282.jpg|[[Ordination]] of [[Nanda]]. Schist. Sahr-i-Bahlol. [[Indian Museum]], [[Calcutta]]. 8. Preaching Buddha, 4th century CE, Sahri Bahlol, Gandhara Gallery, Indian Museum, Kolkata.-NS3935-A23207.jpg|Preaching Buddha. Head of a bodhisattva, Gandhara, Pakistan, Sahri Bahlol, c. 100 AD, schist - San Diego Museum of Art - DSC06345.JPG|Head of a bodhisattva. MET DT235.jpg|Bodhisattva. Standing Bodhisattva. Gandharan (undated), from Sahribahlol. Indian Museum, Calcutta ei05-34.jpg|Standing Bodhisattva. Sahri-Bahlol Buddhas.jpg|Buddha statues. </gallery>

[[File:Rabbi Simon Jacobson at Scott Air Force Base.jpg|thumb|Simon Jacobson speaks at the National Prayer Luncheon at [[Scott Air Force Base]] in 2010]] {{Chabad sidebar}} '''Simon Jacobson''' (born December 8, 1956) is the author of ''[[Toward a Meaningful Life]]'' (William Morrow, 2002), founder of The Meaningful Life Center and publisher of the Yiddish English weekly, The ''[[Algemeiner Journal]]''. Jacobson is a member of the [[Chabad-Lubavitch]] movement.
==Life and early career== Jacobson was born in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], to a [[Chabad]] [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] family. He studied in the [[United Lubavitcher Yeshiva]] and the [[Rabbinical College of America]], and did his post-graduate studies in [[Tomchei Temimim|Central Tomchei Tmimim]]. While still in [[yeshiva]], Jacobson began working extensively as a ''[[choizer]]'' for the talks of Rabbi [[Menachem Mendel Schneerson]] the seventh [[Chabad]] [[rebbe]].<ref name="interview"/>
===Vaad Hanachos Hatemimim=== In 1979, Jacobson began directing a team of scholars known as ''Vaad Hanachos Hatemimim'' that [[choizer|memorized]] and [[meiniach|transcribed]] entire talks that the Lubavitcher Rebbe gave during the [[Shabbat|Sabbath]] and holidays (when writing and tape recording are not permitted under [[Halacha|Jewish Law]]). This team published more than 1,000 of the Rebbe's talks.<ref name="interview"/>
===Sefer HaLikkutim project=== Jacobson was also part of the research team for ''Sefer HaLikkutim'' - an encyclopedic collection of [[Hasidic Judaism|Chassidic]] thought anthologized from the works of the ''[[Tzemach Tzedek]]'' (26 volumes, published 1977-1982).<ref name="interview">[http://www.chabadominican.com/templates/articlecco_cdo/aid/718548/jewish/Toward-a-Meaningful-Life-with-Simon-Jacobson.htm Interview with Simon Jacobson] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808235940/http://www.chabadominican.com/templates/articlecco_cdo/aid/718548/jewish/Toward-a-Meaningful-Life-with-Simon-Jacobson.htm |date=2009-08-08 }}, Chabadominican.com</ref>
==The Meaningful Life Center== Jacobson heads The Meaningful Life Center, called a "spiritual Starbucks" by [[The New York Times]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/29/nyregion/29synagogue.html|title=Synagogue, and ‘Spiritual Starbucks’|date=29 September 2008|work=The New York Times}}</ref> He is a sought-after speaker in the Jewish world today.<ref>http://www.5tjt.com/news/read.asp?Id=4659{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He has lectured to diverse audiences on six continents and in forty states on psycho-spiritual issues and applying Jewish thought to contemporary life. He has been interviewed on over 300 radio and TV shows, including CNN with [[Larry King Live|Larry King]], [[Charlie Rose (talk show)|Charlie Rose]], and the CBS News Show “The Best of Us.” In 2010, Rabbi Jacobson appeared in the award-winning film, [[The Human Experience]].
===''Toward a Meaningful Life''=== Jacobson is the author of the book ''[[Toward a Meaningful Life]]'', a [[William Morrow and Company|William Morrow]] publication that has sold more than 300,000 copies and has been translated into [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[French language|French]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[German language|German]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], Polish and [[Czech language|Czech]].<ref name="askmoses.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.askmoses.com/en/scholar/2060780/Rabbi-Simon-Jacobson.html|title=Rabbi Simon Jacobson - Askmoses Resident Scholar - Judaism Jewish History Expert|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Chabad South Hills News|url=http://www.incommunitymagazines.com/content/chabad-south-hills-news|agency=IN Community Magazine|location=Pittsburgh, PA:|quote=The [[Rohr Jewish Learning Institute]] (JLI) will present Toward a Meaningful Life: A Soul-Searching Journey for Every Jew....Although the course is prepared by Rabbi Simon Jacobson, head of the Meaningful Life Center in New York City and author of the best-selling book Toward a Meaningful Life, the sessions are freestanding and no prior familiarity with the book is assumed.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216230020/http://www.incommunitymagazines.com/content/chabad-south-hills-news|archivedate=2014-12-16|df=}}</ref>
==The Algemeiner== Jacobson is also the publisher of the Yiddish English Weekly, ''The Algemeiner Journal''. Many of his writings are syndicated on other Chabad websites, including [[Chabad.org]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chabad.org/search/keyword_cdo/kid/197/jewish/Simon-Jacobson.htm|title=Browse by Author|publisher=}}</ref> and [[AskMoses.com]].<ref name="askmoses.com"/>
==Publications== ===Books=== *''Toward a Meaningful Life'', 1995 {{ISBN|978-0-9612088-1-3}} *''Spiritual Guide to Counting the [[Counting of the Omer|Omer]]'', 1996 {{ISBN|0-06-051190-7}} *''60 DAYS: A Spiritual Guide to the [[High Holidays]]'', 2003 {{ISBN|1-886587-24-8}}
==Personal life== Jacobson married on February 21, 1983, and has two children. His brother is Yosef Yitzchak Jacobson, a Chabad rabbi and the dean and Rosh Yeshiva of [[theyeshiva.net]],<ref>[http://theyeshiva.net/Teacher/View/1 theyeshiva.net Dean] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100609183313/http://theyeshiva.net/Teacher/View/1 |date=June 9, 2010 }}</ref> who was the first rabbi invited by [[the Pentagon]] to present the annual [[keynote address]] to the US military Chief of Chaplains Senior Leadership Training Conference.<ref>[http://lubavitch.com/news/article/2022350/Chabad-Rabbi-First-Rabbi-Ever-to-Address-U-S-Military-Chaplaincy.html lubavitch.com/news First Rabbi to Address Chaplaincy]</ref>
==References== {{reflist|32em}}
==External links== *[http://www.meaningfullife.com/ Rabbi Jacobson's Homepage - Meaningfullife.com]

[[File:Tempel-ezbet rushdi.jpg|thumb|Plan of the temple]] The [[ancient Egypt]]ian '''Temple of Ezbet Rushdi''' was discovered near the modern village of Ezbet Rushdi el-Saghira – itself just north of [[Tell el-Dab'a]], the ancient [[Avaris]] – and dates to the [[Twelfth Dynasty]].<ref name=rw>{{cite book|last=Wilkinson|first=Richard H.|authorlink=Richard H. Wilkinson|title=The Complete Temples of Ancient Egypt|year=2000|publisher=Thames & Hudson|location=New York|isbn=0-500-05100-3|p=109}}</ref> It was first excavated from 1951 by Shehata Adam who was working for the [[Egyptian Antiquities Service]].<ref>S. Adam: ''Report on the Excavations of the Department of Antiquities at Ezbet Rushdi'', in: ''ASAE'' 56 (1959), 207–226.</ref> The temple was again excavated in 1996 by an Austrian mission under [[Manfred Bietak]].<ref>Ernst Czerny, [http://www.auaris.at/html/ezbet_en.html Ezbet Rushdi] www.auaris.at</ref>
The [[Egyptian temple|temple]] complex has a layout that is typical of the [[Middle Kingdom of Egypt|Middle Kingdom]] temples.<ref name=rw/> It measures 31 × 41.5 m and was built of [[mudbrick]]s.<ref>Ernst Czerny: ''Tell el-Dab'a XXII, "Der Mund der beiden Wege", Die Siedlung und der Tempelbezirk des Mittleren Reiches von Ezbet Ruschdi, Volume 1'' Vienna 2015, {{ISBN|9783700169949}}, p. 133</ref> According to the first excavator Shehata Adam, the temple was built by king [[Amenemhat I]]; a stela found here dates to king [[Senusret III]] and it seemed likely that the latter expanded the temple during his own reign.<ref name=rw/>
However, the Austrian excavations showed that under the temple stretched an older settlement, which could be dated by pottery to the first half of the 12th dynasty. The temple itself was given a new construction date at c. the mid-12th dynasty, probably at year 5 of Senwosret III, as indicated by the above-mentioned stela.<ref>Ernst Czerny: ''Tell el-Dab´a XXII'', vol 1, pp. 82–85</ref> The entrance was on the north side, where the walls were stronger and it seems that they formed a brick [[Pylon (architecture)|pylon]]. The entrance was at one time perhaps framed by inscribed limestone slabs.<ref>Ernst Czerny: ''Tell el-Dab´a XXII'', vol 1, p. 90</ref> The proper temple stood within an open courtyard. On the west side behind the main gate there was small temple, while the main one was opposite the north entrance. Behind the entrance of the temple proper stood a courtyard with perhaps eight columns. Some stone column bases were still found. East and west of this courtyard were on either side two smaller chambers, while on the south side were three cult chapels. This temple was placed within a larger complex. On the east side were excavated remains of storage and administrative buildings.
In the temple several statues of high officials and of kings were found.<ref>Ernst Czerny: ''Tell el-Dab'a XXII'', vol 1, pp. 427–440</ref>

{{Multiple issues|{{POV|date=May 2017}}{{citation style|date=May 2017|details=confusing citation style}}}}
'''The Book of the Highest Initiation''' (also known as “The Book of the Policy and the Highest Initiation” - Arabic: “Kitab as-Siyasa wa’l-Balagh al-Akhbar”) is a text that falsely claims to be of [[Isma'ilism|Ismaili]] origin and is wrongfully attributed to ‘Ubayd Allah, or [[Abdullah al-Mahdi Billah]], the first [[Fatimid Caliphate|Fatimid]] Caliph-Imam.<ref>{{cite book|title=The New Encyclopedia of Islam|date=2013|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|edition=Fourth|page=202|last1=Glassé|first1=Cyril}}</ref> The work is clearly a false account of Ismaili initiation and was written with the intent of denigrating [[Isma'ilism|Ismaili]] beliefs and practices.
== The author == The actual creator of this text is unknown, but evidence reveals that the author constructed this false account of Ismaili initiation rituals as part of a larger anti-[[Fatimid Caliphate|Fatimid]] propaganda campaign initiated by [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]] supporters in the 10th century.
== The work == By the tenth century, the [[Fatimid Caliphate|Fatimid]] Caliphate posed a dangerous threat to [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]] hegemony. In response to this threat, the Abbasid Caliph initiated a large-scale propaganda campaign to challenge the legitimacy of Fatimid Caliphs and to present [[Isma'ilism|Ismailism]] as an un-Islamic [[heresy]] that is a danger to [[Muslim]]s. For example, texts such as the [[Baghdad Manifesto]], which was written and signed by [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]] scholars, claimed that the [[Fatimid Caliphate|Fatimid]] Caliph-Imams were not descendants of ‘[[Ali]]. But other texts, like '''The Book of the Highest Initiation''', were created to appear as genuine Ismaili works.
The full text of '''The Book of the Highest Initiation''' does not survive, but scholar S.M. Stern has reconstructed the text of the pamphlet using several sources.<ref>{{cite book|title=Studies in Early Ismāʻīlism|publisher=Brill|location=Jerusalem|pages=56–83|last1=Stern|first1=S.M.|authorlink1=The ‘Book of the Highest Initiation’ and Other Anti-Ismaili Travesties}}</ref>
The text claims to be a letter written by Fatimid Caliph-Imam [[Abdullah al-Mahdi Billah]] to his missionaries working to convert people to [[Isma'ilism|Ismailism]]. It is written as an instruction manual, organized into 35 short paragraphs.
The account begins with instruction about how to attract converts from a multitude of different backgrounds, including [[Christian]]s, [[Jews]], [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrians]], [[Manichaeism|Manichaeans]], philosophers, and [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] Muslims.
The pamphlet instructs that initiates must swear an oath before the missionaries begin to reveal more about their beliefs. It goes on to claim that there are 7 grades of initiation, each one moving closer and closer to total sacrilege. At the final stage, the initiate is “dispensed from the religious practices” altogether.<ref>{{cite book|title=Studies in Early Ismāʻīlism,|date=1983|publisher=Brill|location=Jerusalem|page=71|last1=Stern|first1=S.M.}}</ref>
The goal of this text was to present [[Isma'ilism|Ismailism]] as a system that leads to complete departure from religion. Its depicts the faith as not only foreign to Islam, but also insidiously dangerous to it.
The contents of this fabricated text do not reflect the beliefs or practices of Ismailis. It is true, however that the Fatimid [[Dawah|da’wah]] system was engaged in recruiting converts to their faith throughout the [[Dar al-islam|dar al-Islam]]. These [[Da'i|Da’is]] were successful in attracting converts from a wide range of background. The author of The Book of the Highest Initiation, clearly threatened by the success of these missions, intentionally demeans the Ismaili mission and accuses it of manipulating its adherents into disbelief and departure from religion.
== The legacy ==
This work has had a large influence on the historical depiction and understanding of [[Isma'ilism|Ismailism]]. The idea that there were ‘7 grades of initiation’ had a particularly long afterlife.
Because authentic Ismaili documents were available to a general readership until recently, slanderous and fabricated works such as this one were thought to be accurate depictions of Ismaili religion.
S.M. Stern relates that even in the beginning of the 20th century, some Western academics thought that this account revealed the “secret doctrine of the [[Isma'ilism|Isma’ilis]].”<ref>{{cite book|title=Studies in Early Ismāʻīlism|date=1983|publisher=Brill|location=Jerusalem|page=58|last1=Stern|first1=S.M.}}</ref>
With the publication and circulation of authentically Ismaili texts, a wide non-Ismaili readership can now recognize the falsity of this text and appreciate the genuine teachings of the [[Isma'ilism|Isma’ili]] [[Dawah|da’wah]].
== References == {{reflist}} * Glassé, Cyril. The New Encyclopedia of Islam. Fourth Edition. Lanham, Maryland: Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, 2013.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D7tu12gt4JYC&pg=PA202&lpg=PA202&dq=book+of+the+highest+initiation+fatimid&source=bl&ots=9odUqkNE3N&sig=R2ffV_3w6fKCZASzwZVeur-CQeA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAtbf8o7fTAhUMziYKHaZNDr8Q6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The New Encyclopedia of Islam|last=Glassé|first=Cyril|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780742562967|language=en}}</ref> * Stern, S. M. “The ‘Book of the Highest Initiation’ and Other Anti-Ismaili Travesties.” In ''Studies in Early Ismāʻīlism'', 56-83. Max Schloessinger Memorial Series. Jerusalem: Magnes Press, Hebrew University; Leiden: E.J. Brill, 1983.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Studies_in_Early_Ism%C4%81%CA%BB%C4%ABlism.html?id=bWXYAAAAMAAJ|title=Studies in Early Ismāʻīlism|last=Stern|first=Samuel Miklos|date=1983-01-01|publisher=Magnes Press, Hebrew University|isbn=9789652233882|language=en}}</ref> <references />

{{Unreferenced|date=April 2008}} '''Unsibanbon''' (原始反本) is one of the main teachings of [[Jeung San Do]]. Wun(原) means "origin" or "primitive" and Shi(始) means "beginning" or "start". Ban(反) means "reverse" or "opposite" and Bon(本) means "origin" or "base". Its literal meaning is that returning to the origin.
== How Unsibanbon appears in our daily life? == Before understanding Unsibanbon further, it is recommended that you understand both [[Cosmic year (Chinese astrology)|Cosmic year]] and [[Gaebyeok]] because Unsibanbon can be explained in more detail in the context of Cosmic year.
The one constant in the universe is change, and at the time of the Autumn [[Gaebyeok]], the direction of that change is returning to the origin. In our lives we often have the desire to return to our origins whether it means returning home after a long journey, discovering our ethnic and cultural roots, seeking the original purpose of our lives, or returning to the origin of life through meditation. The practice of returning to the origin is discovering who we truly are. It can also entail solving a problem at its root.
== Why Unsibanbon is important? == According to the eastern philosophy, everything is changing and it has its own cycle. It is not difficult to find a cycle. Even our planet earth has its own cycle. Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter. This cycle is divided with four different seasons, but the principle below is always [[Yin yang|yin and yang]].
When yang (positive energy) reaches its end, it must return to its origin. Just like a cannonball shot to the sky directly, it goes up to the sky and at a certain point, it returns to the ground. This action of return at the turning point is called Geukjeukban (克卽反).
As it is explained above, earth's four seasons can be contained in [[Yin yang|yin and yang]]. Spring and summer represent yang (positive energy) and autumn and winter represents yin (negative energy).
When summer reaches its end (end of positive energy), just like a cannonball reaches its turning point, it returns to its origin from its farther-reached-end.
This principle is important because Unsibanbon is happening regardless we acknowledge it or not. Also, it is important to accept and do our action with Unsibanbon this time of our life because it is natural like a shot cannonball returning to the ground from the sky. For this reason, many people meditate to be back to their origin.
Quote from [[Dojeon]]
:There is dao. :within dao there is virtue. :from virtue there is edification. :from edification there is growth. :with growth there are people. :from people there are multitudes. :there is one person the multitudes would want to uphold. :they would uphold a sage king like Yao. :Dojeon 4:87:2-9
==See also== * [[Boeun]] (Offering Gratitude and Repayment) 報恩 * [[Cosmic year (Chinese astrology)|Cosmic Year]] ** [[Shao Yung]] * [[Dojang]] Dao center 道場 * [[Dojeon]] Sacred text of Jeung San Do 道典 * [[Gaebyeok]] * [[Haewun]] (Resolution of Bitterness and Grief) 解怨 * [[Jeung san do|Jeung San Do]] * [[Sangjenim]] 上帝 * [[Sangsaeng]] (Mutual life-giving) 相生 * [[Tae Eul Ju]] mantra 太乙呪 * Taemonim 太母

[[File:CoronaRecesvinto01.JPG|thumb|320px|Detail of a suspended votive crown from [[Visigothic]] Spain, before 672 AD. Part of the [[Treasure of Guarrazar]] offered by [[Reccesuinth]]. Out of view are chains for suspension above, and a Byzantine pendant cross below. Alternate view.<ref>[[:File:Tesoro de Guarrazar (M.A.N. Madrid) 01.jpg|Another view]]</ref> ]] A '''votive crown''' is a [[votive offering]] in the form of a [[crown (headgear)|crown]], normally in precious metals and often adorned with jewels. Especially in the [[Early Middle Ages]], they are of a special form, designed to be suspended by chains at an altar, [[shrine]] or image. Later examples are more often typical crowns in the style of the period, either designed to be placed on the head of a statue, or re-used in this way after donation.
==Pre-Christian examples== There were pagan votive crowns in the ancient world, although these are essentially known only from literary references. [[Vitruvius]] records that when [[Hiero II of Syracuse]] (died 215 BC) suspected his goldsmith of cheating him over the making of a votive crown for a statue in a temple, for which he had supplied the gold to be used, he asked [[Archimedes]] to devise a test. This led Archimedes to his famous ''[[Eureka (word)|eureka]]'' moment, after he realized he could test the crown by comparing its [[displacement (fluid)|displacement]] of water to that of the same weight of pure gold; in fact the goldsmith had taken some gold and added silver instead.<ref>Rossi & Russo, 11-12. [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Vitruvius/9*.html Vitruvius text], see sections 9-12.</ref> From other references, it seems that in classical times not just statues of the gods, but also living rulers were presented with crowns in the hope of a favourable response to a request.
==Suspended votive crowns== The largest number of surviving examples of the Christian Early Medieval suspended type come from 7th century [[Visigoth]]ic [[Hispania]], especially the [[Treasure of Guarrazar]], from near [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]], which includes no fewer than twenty-six examples in gold, probably hidden as the [[Muslim conquests|Muslim invasion]] drew near. These were excavated in 1859, and are now divided between the [[National Archaeological Museum of Spain]] in Madrid and the [[Musée de Cluny]] in Paris.<ref name=musee>[[Musée de Cluny]], [http://www.musee-moyenage.fr/pages/page_id18361_u1l2.htm webpage with another crown] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317142133/http://www.musee-moyenage.fr/pages/page_id18361_u1l2.htm |date=2010-03-17 }}, accessed May 20, 2010 (in French).</ref> However the type was originally Roman or Byzantine, and adopted widely across Europe;<ref name=stokstad84>Stokstad, 84</ref> nearly all these have been lost, as the objects were naturally extremely vulnerable to theft or looting. These could not be worn, as they were too small and also very often had [[pendilia]], or dangling ornaments on chains hanging from the main crown, often with jewels and perhaps formed into letters which spelled a word or phrase. In the example above, the letters on the pendilia spell "RECCESVINTHVS REX OFFERET", or "King [[Recceswinth]] offered this".<ref name=stokstad84/> These royal donations signified the submission of the monarchy to God.<ref name=musee/> Such objects were probably influenced by the thirty suspended gold crowns placed round the main altar of [[Hagia Sophia]] by [[Justinian]], now lost,<ref>Stokstad, 84; Beckwith, 345</ref> although the Christian practice is at least as old as the 4th century.<ref>Chopin, Danielle Gaborit.[https://books.google.com/books?id=qtgotOF0MKQC&pg=PA390&dq=Votive+crown&hl=en&ei=6zn0S528K4KC8gan7737DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Votive%20crown&f=false ''Encyclopedia of the Middle Ages''] "Crown, art", edited by André Vauchez, Richard Barrie Dobson, Michael Lapidge, Volume 1, page 390.</ref>
The main body of suspended crowns is usually flat around the top as well as the bottom rim; some are merely an open framework of flexibly linked metal pieces. Such crowns were probably found widely across Christian Europe in this period; the will of 572 of Aredius, a wealthy friend of [[Gregory of Tours]] in [[Gaul]], describes a crown that sounds very similar in form to the Spanish examples.<ref>Fletcher, 62</ref> The [[Iron Crown of Lombardy]] was perhaps originally made as a votive crown, although it was later used for the [[coronation]] of monarchs including [[Napoleon I]]. Another gold crown was a source of contention in [[Constantinople]]; it was given to the [[Maurice (emperor)|Emperor Maurice]] (r. 582-602) by his wife [[Constantina (empress)|Constantina]] and the [[dowager]] [[Sophia (empress)|Empress Sophia]] for Easter 601, intended to be worn by him. Instead, he had it suspended by chains over the main altar of Hagia Sophia, upsetting the two ladies.<ref>Garland, Linda [http://www.roman-emperors.org/tina.htm Online biography of Constantina]</ref> It hung there for nearly two centuries, until [[Leo IV the Khazar|Emperor Leo IV]] coveted it and took it for his own use. In a suspiciously neat story, the crown was richly decorated with [[Carbuncle (gemstone)|carbuncles]] (jewels), and Leo, who was an [[Byzantine iconoclasm|iconoclast]], soon after died of an outbreak of [[carbuncle]]s (abscesses), allowing the church to draw the obvious conclusion; other stories said his wife had poisoned him.<ref>Treadgold, 370, though he says the crown was a different one, given by [[Heraclius]]</ref> Another Byzantine votive crown, given by [[Leo VI the Wise|Leo VI]] (r. 886-912) is now in the Treasury of [[San Marco, Venice]], and is decorated with [[cloisonné enamel]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://i154.photobucket.com/albums/s279/desniza/VI.jpg|title=Image of Leo VI's crown|publisher=}}</ref>
==Statue votive crowns== [[File:Maria de las angustias 1.JPG|thumb|300px|One of many crowned statues of the [[Virgin Mary]] carried in the processions of [[Holy Week in Seville]].]] In England, a later medieval source says that [[King Canute]] gave a, or "his", crown to be placed on or over ("super caput") the head of the [[rood]], or large [[crucifix]], in [[Winchester Cathedral]] (other notables decorated statues with their jewellery or a sword).<ref>Dodwell, 212,</ref> The ''[[Anglo-Saxon Chronicle]]'' records that [[Hereward the Wake]]'s men looted a solid gold crown from the head of the rood on the main altar of [[Peterborough Cathedral]] in 1070.<ref>Dodwell, 213,</ref> The [[Romanesque art|Romanesque period]] saw the height of crowned images of Christ, who is often shown wearing a crown on the cross in wood and metal figures, and manuscript illuminations, and also the introduction of crowned images of the [[Virgin Mary]] in the West, as the concept of Mary as [[Queen of Heaven]] became increasingly prominent.
A very small late medieval crown now in the Treasury of [[Aachen Cathedral]] was made for the famously lavish wedding celebrations in 1468 of [[Margaret of York]], [[Duchess of Burgundy]], sister of [[Edward IV of England]], and later placed on a statue of the Virgin Mary as a votive offering. It was designed to be worn on top of an elaborate headress and hairstyle, or perhaps on a [[hennin]], and is much smaller than a conventional crown for wearing directly on the head.<ref>[http://www.culture24.org.uk/asset_arena/7/88/22887/v0_master.jpg Image of Margaret's crown] Schitker, 105-111 explores the donation in detail.</ref> This is now a rare example of a medieval votive crown that has survived above ground. A few years later, in 1487, the crown that had been used by the pretender [[Lambert Simnel]] was given to a statue of the Virgin in Dublin.<ref>Schnitker, 110</ref>
Crowns designed solely for statues became increasingly elaborate, especially in the [[Baroque]] period, and in the Spanish world; they often have a flat radiating "[[sunburst]]" around them, in the style used for [[monstrance]]s, as in the example illustrated. Statues of the Virgin Mary and the [[Infant Jesus]], of the [[Infant Jesus of Prague]] type, are among those most commonly crowned. The [[Crown of the Andes]] is a votive crown from [[Colombia]] in gold with 450 [[emerald]]s, apparently made between the late 16th and 18th centuries, perhaps originally as an offering in thanks for the city of [[Popayán]] being spared from a plague. It is now in private hands in the US.<ref>Norman, Geraldine, [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/crowning-glory-of-the-andes-1587131.html ‘Crowning Glory of the Andes’]: ''The Independent on Sunday'', 18 June 1995. The crown was not in fact sold.</ref>
==Contemporary examples== Votive crowns have continued to be produced in Catholic countries in modern times. Often such crowns were kept in the [[church treasury]] except for special occasions such as relevant feast-days, when they are worn by the statue. Christ and the Virgin Mary are frequently conventionally shown wearing crowns in Christian art, in subjects such as the [[Coronation of the Virgin]], and are the most common figures to be crowned, but other saints may also be given crowns, especially if the saint was royal, or a [[martyr]], as martyrs are promised crowns in heaven by many texts.
In Greece a [[Tama (votive)|''tama'']] or votive offering of, or depicting, two small wedding crowns, as used locally, indicates a request for a good marriage. Actual crowns used in ceremonies were normally retained by the couple.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=o8JlWxBYs40C&pg=PA90&dq=Greek+wedding+crown&cd=1#v=onepage&q=Greek%20wedding%20crown&f=false Marriage Customs of the World].</ref>
==See also== {{commonscatinline|Votive crowns}}
